item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Our website address is: http://marco.mikesmithdesign.co.uk.

What personal data we collect and why we collect it

Comments

When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor’s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymised string created from your e-mail address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service Privacy Policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Contact forms

Cookies

If you leave a comment on our site you may opt in to saving your name, e-mail address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you have an account and you log in to this site, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Analytics

Who we share your data with

How long we retain your data

If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognise and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where we send your data

Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

Your contact information

Additional information

How we protect your data

What data breach procedures we have in place

What third parties we receive data from

What automated decision making and/or profiling we do with user data

Industry regulatory disclosure requirements

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
My name is Marco Ciuffini and I have left to wander the world, I like to live in new places for long periods of time to get to know a place. I enjoy the coffee shops, the language, the bars and of course the natives.

I am working as an English Teacher and a web designer/programmer and I am touring the world writing down my beautiful, funny, awkward, stressful experiences as I go

Enjoy

item.title: Whatever
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
I made it.


I keep thinking to myself why the fuck am I here. In both a positive and negative way. What am I doing in a foreign country with no idea how to speak Portuguese and no idea what I'm going to do. This briefly scares me and I wonder if I made a good decision.


The flipside is "I cant believe I'm here in Rio De Janeiro with no idea what I'm going to do, but I could do anything from here" and that is far more exciting. These thoughts and feeling come and go in waves. Much like the beaches I sit on ;)


This trip for me is about having that freedom, back home due to nobody's fault I felt like I wasn't moving forward, I wasn't happy and had no idea what to do. If I feel confused and indecisive I may as well be on the beaches of Copacabana and Ipanema, and see where it takes me.


I've decided to write this because I don't know where it might lead and I want to share this with those I love and like along with pictures. I also wish to be brutally honest about everything, how I'm feeling, what I'm thinking and my experiences along the way. There will be times when I'm feeling low and lonely and wish to pack it in and come home, more than anything this may be a therapy for me. There will also be times of extreme happiness and pleasure which I wish to share with you, I hope more of the latter.
There is two sides to travelling and living abroad as with all walks of life and I wish not to just share the great views and places I visit but also the thoughts and feelings I experience within this. I feel like I cannot do that in pictures alone and I don't want to create a facade that I'm living the high life when I'm not. I want to share honestly how I'm doing with y'all. For better or for worse.

I hope you enjoy

Cause sometimes my words wont do it

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: This is such a lovely idea, Marco. I'm looking forward to following your geographical and emotional journey <3 also........ trip out to visit with a gang?! Yes please! J xxx

item.title: Ups and Downs
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
Domingo

As you can see, I've already learned lots of Portuguese. On the first taxi ride I realised I'm going to struggle to communicate, the bits I've learned from Duolingo helped very little. There were 0 cats reading newspapers.

Since then I've already come along way, my most recent taxi ride involving several discussions including him explaining his higher tariffs. Thanks to all the natives at the hostel I picked up many useful and some not so useful phrases but have been able to communicate and make myself understood. One worker telling me I talk too much. Shock

But its been tough, very much a baptism of fire (a phrase I have enjoyed recently), being thrown in at the deep end to speak Portuguese almost constantly, writing things down and even in my chill time trying to learn. Its a constant stress to not only socialise in the hostel but in an alien language. I guess this is what I signed up for though and my favourite times so far have not been the beautiful beaches or the many cervejas but have been learning the language from the locals and reciprocating lessons back.

I still get waves of anxiousness matched by waves of happy disbelief, but now becoming mixed with times of comfort, and of awkwardness. I feel it in a flux, a struggle to get out of bed in the morning accompanied by facebook and instagram scrolling before buzzfeed posts about tumblr laughing me into positivity to start the day.

This gets a Mario kart esque boost from a coffee and breakfast which leads to a feeling of happy shivers alongside contentment (usually at the beach, today with added beach football) fuelling me through the afternoon of socialising before I crash either into a nap or a period of self deprecation or both.

Today that involved heading up to Christ the Redeemer on a whim, however when at the top I was ironically feeling kinda low. This did nothing to take away from the vast views which were beyond stunning. Llow the statue, Christ is alright but the views around it should be deemed the redeemer. Things changed though as I had another coffee at the top and wrote in my personal diary. It cleared out my head of things I guess I've struggled to communicate here and at home which was perhaps the inspiration for this 'blog'.

I came down on a bit of a buzz and chilled to write this alongside a beer, knowing what I have to do, to keep moving forward. To now move onto what I came here to do. Find a place I like, find people I belong with and settle into it.

item.title: A Little Less Conversation
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
Yesterday I saw one of my favourite things I've ever seen, better than Christ the redeemer for sure. I wandered into the centre in my shirt to look for work and stumbled across a bowl besides a large building under construction. With many people looking on, the construction workers had decided to take a rather lengthy lunch break in which they were playing scorpion football.

Joga Bonito

for those of you familiar with the phrase or the adverts from the noughties, its 3 v 3, first to two goals in a winner stays on format. It seems the rules are:

  1. anyone can play although not if you've been on too recently
  2. shoes are not required but any shoe is accepted, one gentleman opting for one shoe on, one shoe off.
  3. go in hard but not too hard, if anyone fell over it was deemed too hard, although there was no diving
  4. do not get megged or skinned

In the case of the latter you'd become subjected to the crowd whooping and hollering and laughing at you. it better not result in a goal.

The ball stayed on the floor for pretty much the whole time unless a player was trying to flick it over or round you, and the ball control these guys had in work boots was unbelievable. Their movement, quick passing and racy flicks showcased the real Brazilian flair we've come to know. Three players in particularly stood out.

One shoe - who's tactic was clearly thought out as at a moments notice his bare foot toepoke could pwn the ball through the smallest of gaps into the miniature goal

Blake Griffin - a late arrival, sporting ripped overalls, but was nothing short of a magician with the ball at his boots.

And the Monster - a huge guy who was strong, smart and could do anything with the ball at his feet, he controlled and dominated most games and appeared rather frequently. Although I would not be one to tell him no.

I don't know if this a daily, weekly or impromptu occurrence but I could have wasted the whole day there, the football was mesmerising, there were characters apparent and all around everyone seemed to be thoroughly enjoying it. Businessmen watching on, tourists videoing and taking pictures. Friends and family shouting and cheering, and salesmen selling acai and ice cream nearby (although I seemed to be the only sucker to bite).

Brazil seems to be in economic decline at the moment and it could be due to these lengthy lunch breaks, the fact everyone seems to spend their time in coffee shops or an actual reason that I cant understand, but sat watching the workers in this arena has been my favourite moment so far. And my money is going further every day. So keep up the good work breaks!

This does however mean work and visas are less likely and work may not be legit. I still don't know what I'm doing but that's fine. I could volunteer on a paradise beach for a few months, look for work elsewhere, hell I may even just chill it for a few months and do a ski season. I still don't know but I'm feeling more relaxed about it and know there are many opportunities, ill just see where the wind takes me.

As my mum said to me today quoting Winnie the pooh, who has the best way of life imo,

"doing nothing always leads to the very best something"

Well I feel ya pooh and now I'm moving hostels to go enjoy the weekend. I am in Rio after all.

item.title: Flamengo Chants
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
Ok so the other day I told you I saw the most amazing thing. That has already been replaced.

Before I begin, I have been measuring my Portugues based on communication with taxi drivers. Not a great yard stick I know cause its dependent on their personality and knowledge of English but each time I am understanding more and more and we can have longer conversations. This guy was a big Vasco de Gama fan telling me of past successes, Juninho Pernambucano and his famous free kick, Coutinho, who I later discovered only played 19 games whilst on loan, and how they rinse flamengo for not having estadio. Showing me videos on his phone whilst driving and filming me giving shit to his Flamengo friends which enthused him massively.

Well I'm sorry to Flamengo fans and I'm glad they don't have a stadium, because they play in the Maracana and the atmosphere there last night was the greatest thing I've ever seen. The estadio was full of fans in red and black, minus the quarter for away fans, and they did not stop singing, the whole game. We were stood close to the group of fans leading it and I say stood because the whole crowd was stood up, more peoples feets were on seats than were peoples asses.

The game was alright, 3rd postion Flamengo dominating against 3rd from bottom, as the Irish lad next to me exclaimed - the equivalent of Man United vs Derby. But the fans made it seem as if it was a champions league semi. Backed by the beat of a samba esque drum who kept in rhythm for the whole game, only silent for half time and the first 3 minutes of the second half. He would occasionally slow the pace as the crowd built until a faster beat began prompting the crowd to release all their energy in loud chants of Flamengo along with a slow arm throw. We all became very caught up in it. Beers were about Â£1.60 and delivered to the seats like popcorn sellers. Amazing

They won 1-0 and I don't think I could've handled more goals, the whole 90 minutes being very intense.

On the way down they did not walk down, huddled up, scurrying to go, but danced and sang almost as a collective unit. With the drumming.

My pockets were shit so I held my phone and wallet in my hand tightly, a danish guy we were with had had his phone pickpocketed on the way in. So holding it seemed a good idea, but a guy flew past, tried to grab them out my hand on the way through. He did not succeed gave me a scared look and continued to bustle through. Maybe stupid but also worked, so I feel validated. Although I then wrapped it up in the vest I was swinging round with the other hand, a much safer idea.

It was honestly the best atmosphere I've ever seen at a football game and sorry dad but I now love the drums in the stadium and will debate this with you forever. The whole game was a rhythmic dance and the Maracana will go down as the best club I've been to. Anywhere.

Flamengo Chants

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Can't believe it beats the Kenny under floodlights ð. Okay but not sure the drum at Wycombe or Accrington is quite the same ð, glad you loved it x

item.title: Pusha Man
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
So lol at me and my shit pockets, my phone got jacked last night (I think) out of my pocket as I believe we were heading to the first bar. I couldn't be sure if I had brought it out after I felt someone brush past. I just suddenly felt lighter. He was swift and light fingered the cheeky bastard. So contact me on facebook messenger if you need me until I go get a new phone either tomorrow or Monday.

This did nothing to ruin the day, in truth I barely cared as it was almost an inevitable at some point, just happened a bit earlier than expected. But the day flowed nicely, a large group of us chilling at the beach in the afternoon, to an attempted hike leading to a successful beer at a bar just atop of a pacified favela. The view was stunning, will post when I get it off a guy who I can only describe as the Fresh Prince himself, with his own Carlton to match.

I did say to mum I was not planning to go a favela and I wasn't but things happened and it was well policed. I also failed you again this morning, sorry mum. An English school owner I had reached out to noticed I'd coached football and suggested meeting to check out a project hes looking to do, in another pacified favela.

So I arrived 10 minutes late to the station, which is pretty on time by Brazil standards I gather, and met with local graffiti artist Landreas who lives there. He walked up with us as they discussed ideas in Portugues. Landreas had reached out to street football companies in London to gain help for their community and this had been passed on. I later theorised I was probably brought to appear as a football coach with no real job possibility, but I got some very helpful advice and enjoyed an interesting experience.

Walking up was an inner battle between wtf am I doing and It'll be fine, and I'm glad I went because it obviously was. The artist was clearly a popular guy in his favela and everyone we met greeted us with warmth and joviality. The group we went to the football 'pitch' with were a fantastic group of guys.

Elvis - the pillar of the community, showing us around, to the church, the pitches and the nursery - who have a better football pitch than the community, clearly they start em young here.

Landreas - the graffiti artist from the favela, need I say more

Mattheus - the cheeky chappy making jokes at everyone we pass, shouting to the women in what I can only assume was cat calling and trying to involve me with lots of hand gesture translation.

These were just normal guys looking to help out their community, yielding to their wife's beckons and just get on with their life. I immediately felt relaxed and spent most of my thoughts on trying to decipher what they were discussing rather than fantasising about drive-bys and stabbings as per the walk up.

On the way down and after a coffee and advice from the English teacher I left in a positive mood with prospects of an apartment. So I celebrated with a cerveja watching the arsenal game feeling good about the move. But the combination of last nights alcohol, the stuffy metro, the earlyish morning, lots of departures from the hostel and the annoyance of the phone debacle were sinking in and I went for one of my self degrading naps. I woke up very confused as to why I'm in Brazil but the groggyness soon wore off and I've stabilised. Possibly to do it all again.

item.title: Street Lights
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
Hello,

Before I begin, a very happy birthday to Holly Ciuffini, My amazing sister in law who I hope has had the best weekend down in Wales topping off what is a well deserved summer!

I didn't plan to post this much but now its just on a when I would like to discuss something/share something I've loved.

I left off to Lapa to go have a party weekend. It was just what I needed, time to enjoy Rio without always thinking of the next step, take my mind off it. Although it was socially hectic.

As discussed the Friday was a cracker, then everyone proceeded to leave.

Now in these kind of hostels from my point of view and it seems a lot of those of whom I discuss it with, can be a lot of effort to constantly be social with new people. Lots of, what is coined, the travellers chat.

"How long you here for?"

"Where have you been?"

"This time I was with the poor people in Bolivia..."

Yada yada yada, I am also guilty of this, for sure (another traveller phrased I've noticed and adopted). Its necessary to a point, first meetings, first things to discover things in common or not in common as it may be. But the point is doing this every night can be draining, although it almost always leads to great friendships and lots of booze filled shenanigans (my favourite) and actually some of the stories are incredible and inspire you to follow their footsteps.

But after going through this on Friday, having a ball with many great people, the majority left and I found myself on Saturday dreading heading downstairs to go through it all again, I'd just made friends! For me its daunting but I also know that it's always fine and actually the best things happen when you jump out of your comfort zone. Everyone's in the same boat and mostly all good people looking for a laugh.

I made myself go down, found a familiar face, discussed his ridiculous night with two of his fellow irishmen and it just flowed from there. All anxieties washed away, people came and went, and it was a more chilled vibe to begin with which built up nicely to our samba night. This time there was dancing and I just find myself falling in love with the culture more and more with every day.

Myself and a girl jumped straight in and began to try emulate their dancing ability. I don't think we did bad actually, it was so much fun. If I ever got asked to do strictly I would take it immediately, as I'm sure mum will be more glad to hear than all of yesterdays post.

Upon return to the dance floor they had created a circle of which people jumped in and out with such good synchronicity that we wondered if they perhaps knew each other and this was almost a show. It seemed only 2 or 3 people in at a time max and if someone jumped in another would leave in the same beat and it just flowed perfectly. Their rhythm was a joy to watch, it had the feel of a tribal ritual around a campfire mixed with fermented sugar drinks. Everyone was just having the best time including myself and the lovely Scottish lady I spent the evening with.

I just find it crazy the contrast between my almost bodily fear of socialising or stepping out of my comfort zone and then what actually happens when I do. I would have thought my body had figured it out by now, my brain has but it has to battle to take that initial jump.

That being said I'm now happy to retire back to the hostel in Ipanema where I have spoke very little to anybody this evening and have just relaxed, ready to begin my attempts to lay down a few roots, however loose. This will return to a slower pace and less updates.

Walking around, the next step seems so clear and has such potential that this time my bodily response was filled with overwhelming excitement rather than apprehension.

This weekend was exactly what I needed.

item.title: One Step at a Time
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
I've lost track of days already, I've been neglectful to my own personal diary and even more neglectful to the learning of Portuguese.

But my attention has turned elsewhere to building a base. I returned to Ipanema to begin laying down some foundations. I had a 3 step plan that seemed so easy.

  1. Get a Laptop
  2. Rent a place
  3. Get a job

As advised the visa was always going to be difficult, and although people do seem to work on tourist visas under the table or even having met a few illegal immigrants, it appears it can be done. But it doesn't really seem legit so I've decided to follow my good friend Poggo and teach online from here to kids in China where the market is and the pay is good. Particularly as the Brazilian currency is still dropping.

It all seemed so easy, simple to do and was flowing into position so perfectly yet with the pace of the Brazilians, one small step at a time. I stumbled into a place I could get for a month for a mere Â£150 with a double bed, desk, TV in a clean flat with some other young people. This is day 1 here. I also bought the laptop on the same day and had applied online. I had received my interview date as Sunday. I'd checked the internet in the place. It was the easiest thing in the world. All the steps occurring naturally and together.

Until I reread the email and the upload speed here does not quite reach the minimum speeds required to teach. Bollocks. I should have been chilled going to bed with a smile on my face dreaming of hammocks and beach football. I had found a place to lay my head, watched films and eat pizza before my life begins. Of course it was not gunna be that simple. Classic

Instead it became quite the opposite, turning into a mini negative spiral, figuring out a plan to make it through the interview elsewhere, devising several back up plans due to inevitable plot twists all the while listening to a backing track of worries about missing or messing up this opportunity. It still might require that but for now I have decided to take a step back. I'm rescheduling my interview.

If I had made it through the interview, I'm then in a position of trying to blag my way through training and working whilst looking for a better place all at a million miles an hour trusting in the internet that got me into this sitch. Fuck that, have I not learned anything from these guys? Take it slow, its all good, tudo bem, hakuna matata

What this "too good to be true" room has done though is give me more time and allow me to hopefully build a stronger base whilst premier league football and movies keep me entertained. It was too good to be true but also too good not to take, and true, some of the others had better internet but they were inhabitable, damp and just shitty, even by my standards of living.

A friend who has lived abroad told me to be patient, it takes time, 3 days ago I was scoffing at this thought, I had several lined up and one I'd claimed, but now I come back tail between my legs, wiser and less naive about the whole thing.

So on I go, first real hurdle, I initially reacted fairly badly and was stressing a bit but pulled myself together with a little help from a few friends who help you see it clearly and for the small hiccup it is. As Harry reminded me this comes with the nature of just heading down South in pursuit of work, its not all gunna go perfectly, and whereas an hour ago this was the perfect life and I must have it, I've realised if it doesn't work out, I'll just be heading down another path. No biggie, I'm actually pretty peaceful about it all and it helps me gain perspective that if this is the biggest worry in my life, I'm ridiculously lucky.

I'll continue to house hunt and in the meantime just be slightly more frugal. By going to the beach, or reading books in hammocks, or watching films with pizza. I think I can handle that.
