item.title: One More Day
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
Last Sunday I was not in the greatest mindset and not feeling particularly good but this has been contrasted by my thoughts and feelings this Sunday. Everything is really coming together.

The week has steadily progressed with each day, I think I'm gunna start plotting how I feel on a graph so I can look back on it.

After Monday's stressful start, Tuesday began much better and what was meant to be a day of Portuguese learning, ended up in a long discussion with my housemate on everything from politics to space + time with stops everywhere along the way such as religion and sexuality.

I've always watched sitcoms and wanted that mid 20's/30's life where they live together, all get along and get up to shenanigans, a la New Girl, Friends and the like. That group, and the sense of belonging to one that can be elusive at times.

No real shenanigans as of yet but we do all get along and hang out, its a great atmosphere in the house and I'm really in a place where I can relax. I love it here.

I then had a provisional date planned for Wednesday with a Brazilian who spoke no English, so I spent the day studying more and more Portuguese. Just incases. It fell through but I wasn't disappointed, I kinda knew it was coming and watched Independence Day in Portuguese instead. I felt good about how much I understood, with the help of subtitles and the added memories of previous viewings.

I ended up learning the language into the early hours of the morning, not because I had to but because I found myself in a real state of flow and had an inspiration to learn. It's also helping me with my patience. When learning a new skill, its doesn't noticeably improve day to day particularly, only upon reflection, similar to the growth of abs when going to the gym or growing your hair. Another thing I'm also putting into action. The hair, not the gym...

So with growing my hair (a big one), the new job, new friends, the language and the coding, I have a lot I'm building slowly.

I found myself in that state of flow again when I began to create a website on Thursday. I think I overestimated myself and tried too much for my first attempt but during those few hours I only had thoughts on how to program before relaxing with a couple of table beers in my beloved Barzinhos, again speaking of important topics.

Friday followed a very similar blueprint, albeit it with more extreme values, getting more crunk and hitting the town with the English trio of online teachers; myself, Maddy + Mark, a group of which I again feel very much part of. They want to call us the super cool kids crew but I defiantly disagree, which is most likely why they want to name us that. All night, we drank, danced and debated; not just the name but politics, energy, sports and pretty much anything. We are a very honest lil' group which lays everything on the table and as I walked home listening to music, I felt completely happy, dancing my way home.

Saturday in turn began slowly but built nicely as myself and Maddy hit up the Maracana, to watch the Fla-Flu, coined many years ago as a classic of the crowds, it's a Rio rivalry spanning many years. It's been labeled as more of a celebration of Brazilian football than a heated rivalry In the same manner as the last game it wasn't the standard of football but the crowd that is the real draw.

We didn't have tickets and went on a whim, scouring outside for ticket touts, of which there were of course many. Many trying to charge extortionate gringo prices. But they had all the power as we had no knowledge of Portuguese or how to get tickets. That was half the fun though, being around the crowds, beer in hand trying to find tickets. I know Ameet gets this feeling (happy now?). We ended up overpaying (relative to Brazil) and sitting in the far from sold out away end of the Fluminense fans. But that's the price you pay for having that attitude, I dig it and it definitely didn't take away from the day, despite the distinguishing of the Flu fans throughout the course of the game.

One beer seller, who brings it to your seats btw, was clearly a Fluminense fan and struggling to hide his emotions (if he was even trying), punching and kicking empty seats, giving the finger to nearby Flamengo fans and spending most of his time with his head in his hands. He can't have been the only one who wasn't happy as after the game, around a corner of which we couldn't see, something was clearly kicking off as policemen on horses were charging in. At one point nearby we saw a man running away from, I shit you not, a policeman chasing him on horseback brandishing a sword. A fucking sword!

We swiftly left to meet some friends at an art museum which was having a ridiculously cool event. I'll be honest, to begin with I wasn't overly keen, I'm not particularly into my modern art and just overall imagining it to be too cool for me.

So, Saturday night in Rio De Janeiro, I'm attending an art museum with funky music, surrounded by art, big hipster crowds and people skating. It was probably one of the coolest places I'll ever be and I loved it. It was a really chilled atmosphere as people just hung around, drinking beer from outside vendors and boogieing to some great music. Everybody was dressed well and looked amazing, many in basketball jerseys, the thing which probably most drew my attention. I was also wearing an old school Miami Heat jersey so probably looked the coolest out of anyone... except for a guy in an old school purple Raptors jersey.

Bastard.

I actually chased him to the toilets weirdly to get a picture but I can't get it off my camera.

I awoke on Sunday in a great mood; I hadn't drank too much, had a clear head from the week, I'd been eating well (not cooking well, but good amounts) and was just generally feeling relaxed. I kept doing stupid little small things but nothing was bothering me. I felt good.

I headed to play our regular football game on Sunday evenings. Each week I've been growing in confidence, and playing better and better despite having to use my basketball shoes! This week we had a strong team and we played some beautiful football. Linking up with Brazilians, Colombians and Irishmen alike to face off against 2 teams of Englishmen, Russians and Argentinians to name a few nationalities. One of the Argies classically bringing down our Colombian trickster in true Argentinian fashion.

But the pace of games and standard of the games was high and once more I found myself fully immersed and focused, having one of my better games.

This sense of flow has become more and more occurrent in all facets of life, including socially, and was exactly what I was looking for, along with the sense of belonging I've found within the football group, the English and the Brazilians.

Usually an over-thinker, I now find in my spare time this thought energy is directed to problem solving or positive reflection whereas in the moment I am becoming locked in to situations around me and things are becoming much more natural.

On top of all of this, I got paid, I passed the probation period of my job and the Basketball season is back tomorrow. Things are all going well.

Now this song, albeit originally about God, for me is more about drawing strength and turning positive, as well as a feel good sound which represents my feelings for the NBA being back in the morrow.

In line with this I now wanna share a post by Kevin Love who despite being a professional Basketball player for our previous rivals, he actually helped me to write my honest feelings here due to his post about his panic attacks and sharing. Writing it down really does help. If its quite long at least scroll down to the bottom.

With mental health awareness day last week, a big thought to those who are suffering but also to everyone, we are not all mentally ill but we all have mental health and its important to look after yours.

Everyone is going through something that we canât see.

The thing is, because we canât see it, we donât know whoâs going through what and we donât know when and we donât always know why. Mental health is an invisible thing, but it touches all of us at some point or another. Itâs part of life. Like DeMar said, âYou never know what that person is going through.â

Mental health isnât just an athlete thing. What you do for a living doesnât have to define who you are. This is an everyone thing. No matter what our circumstances, weâre all carrying around things that hurt â and they can hurt us if we keep them buried inside. Not talking about our inner lives robs us of really getting to know ourselves and robs us of the chance to reach out to others in need. So if youâre reading this and youâre having a hard time, no matter how big or small it seems to you, I want to remind you that youâre not weird or different for sharing what youâre going through.

Kevin Love

Even if its just sharing in a text, us Millenials are getting pretty good at this, and I'm always here to listen, honestly, I've got loads of time.

item.title: Rebirth Of Cool
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
Time was running out on my visa, with 21 days left and still lots to see and do, I attempted to extend my visa. I assembled all the necessary forms and evidence, which was a kerfuffle itself, and had heard/read many horror stories regarding the bureaucracy of Brazil. I was not confident.

On Monday they will switch to a new online system due to the inadequacies of the current one, which have people camping in the airport and waiting the whole day, others being turned away 10 minutes after opening due to filled quotas.

I planned to get there early in what was a 3 day program of naps and not napping to prime myself to be at the peak of tiredness when I needed it most. Shattered, I went to bed at 7:30pm the previous night to wake up at 11:30pm (solid 4 hours), watch the basketball and leave early. But my body didn't agree...

Anytime I sleep before 9 o'clock he thinks I'm napping and wakes me up after a maximum of 2 hours, which is a massive ballache. So anyway, I faffed until the warriors game, considering allowing myself to sleep if I felt like it, but alas, I did not. For chef Curry put on an absolute show. I can only equate it to a long term girlfriend doing something to remind you why you fell so deeply in love with them in the first place. He was incredible and produced a performance that you (and I) can forever relive here...

Its funny, I remember in uni learning about sports teams and the attachment of ones self esteem to their team. When the team wins, they are happy and feel good about themselves; when they lose, they take it as a personal loss. Something very strong in my family. Don't believe me? Try and talk to Dad /Berty after Luton/Arsenal have taken a loss. But for real, I never quite got it, maybe I shouldn't have jumped around teams so much. But with the Warriors, I feel it, the other night when we were struggling to make shots I genuinely felt uncomfortable, and frustrated, and not just with the team, albeit a lot with the team. I was feeling particularly sunken when we missed the shot to win the game. In stark contrast, after Wednesdays game I left for the airport feeling perfectly happy, like nothing could go wrong. It's funny, I now have the love for a team, a particular trait from my father no doubt, but in true rebellious fashion I've rejected football and fallen for basketball. Same same, but different.

Maybe that's why I love a bandwagon, a lil' pick me up, the first team I watched play here, Flamengo, have a game tomorrow against top of the table, a win pulling them within one point with 8 or so games to go, and guess who has the hat? ...It's me ...I have the hat. Vamos.

But I digress, back to the airport. When I got there, I danced through the empty corridor all the way to the foreigners office expecting to be the first one there at 2:30am, being that the office did not open till 8. However, there was already a line of 8 bags surrounded by hippies and immigrants sleeping on benches and mats. There was a leak from the rain and the place stunk, mainly of feet, but also of hippy. I couldn't stand it. I went round the corner to read my book in more pleasant aromas, getting through the whole of the Phantom Tollbooth, an enjoyable read with an 'Alice in Wonderland' vibe and many messages to take from it.

I particularly liked the demons such as Terrible Trivium; demon of petty tasks and worthless jobs, ogre of wasted effort and monster of habit, The Triple Demon of Compromise, who always ended up in circles agreeing to do what nobody wanted and Hopping Hindsight to name but a few. All burdensome traits but all so relative to each of us.

Once I'd finished the book, by 4:30am, the corridor began to gradually fill up and funny enough I met a few people who I'd encountered on my travels, the tourist office becoming a social event for gringos to catch up, like rhinos at a watering hole. As 7 o'clock rolled around, I began to lag, until the call was made to get in line. As we did, a police officer appeared and began handing out tickets. Kicking bags out of the way and skipping those who hadn't got their passport ready to hand. Lucky I wasn't first, I thought. I faffed around to get mine out just in time, being given the 3rd ticket. Beleza. He continued along with this ruthless approach all the way to the end before returning to his hole as we waited for another hour.

In this hour I felt a few waves of self doubt, for no real reason, just telling myself I'd probably filled the form out wrong and was half resigned to trying again. I needed another Curry basket to get me going. I had watched the video above at least twice. Once in, the numbers were called. I handed over my forms and took a seat. I couldn't read 'The Outsider' because I was still a little tense and was reading it at lightning speed which did not work with the small sentences. So, I opted for a Portuguese book I'd been gifted, which was surprisingly easier, activating my mind and taking it off of things and passing time (something Tock from the phantom tollbooth would not be happy with)(he's a watchdog)(a dog with a watch strapped to him). With what felt like no time at all, but had been an hour, I was called up and given my extension. Until 5th Feb.

easy peasy squeezy lemons chilllll.

Out within an hour. Before this I was ready and expecting to write up about the pitfalls of Brazilian immigration but I've gotta say it was as smooth as any bureaucracy I've ever experienced, same as Americans and in fact the student loans in England is way worse. But it should be noted, I was there early and one of the first to be seen, I imagine the others had a longer wait.

So I'm here for another 3 months, living with the same guys, ready to continue my Portuguese and see a few more things. At the moment I won't be able to stay for Carnaval, but I have options and that's a long way off. When I was first at the Christ I remember not feeling as if I was here. Not really sure why I was there or what I was doing, but I can say now that I am here. I feel comfortable. Know what I'm doing and only doing what I want. I've had great chats with people back home including my Nan who I know follows this blog. When I chatted with her about goings on here and there and how I'm growing my hair, she replied "back to normal then" and she's right. I do feel back to normal and back to myself.

I'm doing things that I really want to do, tonight I'll hit up a bar to watch basketball after I've finished this and done some coding. Last night I stumbled upon a bar with half price beer and a live jazz band just jammin, so I took to that. I spent the evening sat picking up the good vibrations, with my ears, following them, letting them lead my mind to thoughts of past, present and future all in a positive light as I continue my next few months here in Brazil.

item.title: By Design
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
Errar

verb

  1. To Fuck Up
  2. The act of being wrong in conduct or judgement
    • "Eu errei - I fucked up"

I like this verb, we don't really have it in English, but I find it useful and have used it frequently, particularly this weekend.

Before though, flashback to last weekend, quite the opposite.

Last Saturday was as nice a day as its been here, or anywhere I've been on earth for that matter. The weather was so warm, the kind of warm that warms your bones to the core and gives you the feeling of a constant hug. Warm. So of course I did as all humans do and flock to the edge of land to sit on sand in less clothing than usual. Well for most people. I was pretty much the same.

After an hour of searching for my friend, due to a Whatsapp location error. I eventually found her and we spent the day lounging, laughing and talking about everything before a couple of sneaky odds ons got us a wee bit more tipsy than we had planned. With the sunset fast approaching I had to finish 4 beers at the pace of a university rugby player. Inhaling suds and sand as the warm feeling throughout my bones was rapidly changing to cold, a feeling I'm sure many of you back home are familiar with. But it actually enhanced the evening as we tipsily jollied around Ipanema hitting up an Irish bar called Shenanigans which would have been my perfect place had it not been Dublin prices. Irish bar, Karaoke, Stout and Basketball.

I have a new hangover routine on Sundays of heading out to a barzinho to consume a cheese pastel with a can of Guarana. It has since been developed by the discovery of something I have found only in strange but rare places back home. The hash brown hot dog. Completing the trifecta of dank.

From here, the rest of last Sunday flowed perfectly. From beginning to end, things were going my way, the sun was shining and a relaxed atmosphere surrounded myself and everyone I came into contact with. It really was a mentality thing. I hit all green men in perfect time on my way to football and once there, scoring the best strike I've ever hit. I couldn't really believe it myself and responded with the shrug that I must have subconsciously picked up from this man. A common feature.

It carried onto the next few days. After many investments and new challenges, things are starting to fall into place, and it feels like my life is beginning. However there always seem to be one more thing to do. One more thing to get, One more thing to see, however small. Will I always be wanting to do one more thing? I feel one day I will get to a point I will settle and be satisfied. But I'm pretty sure people say that about money and continue to chase. But at least I'm moving forward

"Life is like riding a bicycle, to keep your balance you must keep moving"

-  Picture in my brothers guest room/Albert Einstein

It's the whole pursuit of happiness, and that it's not a destination but actually the journey, and tbf at the moment I'm enjoying that too. Learning new skills but doing so in another country seeing some cool shit and meeting different people.

And its warm.

Sometimes I feel content and ready to come home but guys, I honestly don't think I can handle the cold at the moment. If I cant slide down it, what use is the cold weather. I will stay here at least until the temperature rises back home, if not longer.

So on the Thursday I arranged to meet a guy just for a coffee and a chat about visa options. He's an American I met on the corner ð©, that has been living here for 2 years and said he could help and give me advice. Although I must admit he was a bit sketchy from the get go. But what harm could a coffee and a chat do ð©. Well foot in the door technique, next thing I know I've paid for his metro ð© to go to Copacabana (as he had got a 'taxi' to meet me) to meet a guy who can help me. A judge of all people ð©, who hes dragged out of bed ð© on a Thursday afternoon. Hmmm. Anyway on the tube he said many things that didn't add up ð© and was offering things I hadn't asked for ð©ð©. I kept my wits and was ready to leave if I was ever uncomfortable, having nothing on me and staying to places I knew. As I then waited in the coffee shop, he left to get his mate ð© from the bar. He returned slightly stressed this guy had left (angrily he added), probably because I didn't have any documents on me. Obviously not. He proceeded to write down that all he needed was a copie ð© of my passport ð©. So on this I thanked him for his time and left swiftly for the bus home. I was apparently not welcome for his time.

I became angry at myself for even putting myself in that position and returned feeling foolish, knowing I need to be more careful and sceptical. I'm not in Bubbenhall anymore.

But as Friday came around I'd bounced back to positivity and set out on seeing a film in the film festival that has been going on throughout Rio this week. Through availability and time, I found myself watching a Colombian cartoon based on a graphic novel of the childhood of a girl growing up between Ecuador and Columbia. But that was the whole story. Not a lot happened, maybe I would have enjoyed it more if I was an adolescent, an Ecuadorian, or a girl. but alas I am 0 of those things so it didn't really resonate, but pretty cool that I understood most of the Portuguese subtitles. For the rest I always had the English.

Even cooler though was that night I had a date, with a woman from Bahia studying here in Rio. As I napped before, I almost tried talking myself out of it, for no real reason other than nerves and lack of confidence, or maybe just nap crankiness, I can get that confused. But I pulled myself up, donned my only pair of shoes and my matching jumper and headed for the free show across town.

With 15% battery ð© I arrived, relying on location services to find her, not knowing actually what she looked like (Tinder). Upon arrival, across texts (still hadn't found her) she asked me if I remembered to bring food. Obviously not. I'm going to a gig. Not a picnic.

She then resent the message about the gig being free, but you must bring food, I didn't get past the free line of the message clearly and I did wonder why everyone walking past me seemed to have a pack of rice ð©. I hit up the nearby shop after a brief encounter with her as she was going in and thought I'd give em a treat of salt and vinegar crisps ð©, a good British staple. What a legend. 2 big packs. One for me and one for the gig.

As I was tucking in to my crisps I reread it one more time ð©, it needs to be 1kg of non perishables. Fuck sake. Back I go again to try one more time. Choosing to offer another of my ancestral foods in spaghetti. Finally getting in after eating 2 big packs of crisps in the queue (nobody wanted any!), we followed many straight out the door and headed to a barzinho.

Now when we first met I'm sure she thought  'Jesus man, this guy can't speak Portuguese' and she would be right, but we persisted through the first barriers and spoke the whole time in Portuguese. We were understanding each other, speaking more fluently with each beer, as I told her would happen, and laughing and smiling all night. Although be under no illusions, it was nowhere near fluent and on occasions, it would take many attempts to understand, but she continued to do so and we had a great time together. On perfect timing for our exit a group of stilt walkers and performers led a crowd of people down the roads in what is already the beginning of pre-carnaval. A great end to a great date.

Feeling ever more confident now, Saturday began with tiresome work and my second job of betting on the football. Although it doesn't pay particularly well, I enjoy it a lot more and watched the scores come in with, at first belief, and after the pivotal 75th minute with terror, yet another week without pay.

Yes I am in Rio watching Soccer Saturday but that's the absolute beauty, I can do that before heading out to meet my friends and have a few drinks in Rio. Eventually.

Another error, although this time I'm shifting the blame to google. I dunno, maybe shes mad cause I had a date or maybe I tell her to shut up too many times, or make her sing questionable songs but she gave me directions to board a bus to head into Catete. Already pissed off cause its double the charge ð© for no apparent reason, it seemed to be taking a long way round ð©. With the early start this morning, I began to nod off ð©, thinking I'll be fine and will just rest for a few minutes ð©. All the time reminding myself of tales of my other half, Harry ð© who fell asleep on trains and overshot his destination of what is surely a record number of times in a row. 6. I thought it was 4 but on fact checking, I'm assured it was 6 times. 6. In one day. Can we all take a minute to appreciate that.

Anyway I woke up and we were heading away from my destination ð©ð©ð© but not past it. I hoped it might be doing a loop round, forgetting the name on the top of the bus as I got on and I decided to ride it out, pun intended. We then went into a tunnel ð© leading away from my destination, something that had also happened on Wednesday night. It began to move farther and farther away as my friends watched my location on Whatsapp, very confused. I realised where it was heading and got off just in time before it headed over what can only be described as a monster of a bridge to another town. Now stuck in the centre, I ubered back to where I wanted to go, paying 4 times the price I had originally intended. Meus Deus. But I eventually arrived, spending the evening drinking outside, way into the night with good company, conversations and feelings.

I frequently jump to conclusions on these things but recently, everything is flowing again and despite the errors, they are just occurrences, which of course even though never intended, add to the occasion. I think its all a question of mindset; when negative, you notice the negative things and give importance to them whereas when your smiling as my man Louis says, the whole world smiles with you and you recognize the positive things and things begin to gain momentum.

Right now I'm in the positive, but in a contradiction of thought, it could turn negative. Gotta go with it, but right now I'm feeling good having another fantastic day at the beach.

item.title: Peaceful Life
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
I've now been here over a month and been working for over a week.

I can actually feel myself settling, metaphorically nestling into a little burrow. I first arrived basically as a traveller and it was pretty non stop, then I found my place and probably did a little too much of nothing and now I've calibrated and started to develop a little routine that works.

I wake up and spend my mornings encouraging children named Dingding, Coco and Mango to say, no, shout... apple, pear and mangooooooooo! Its actually a great wake up, helped by Brazilian coffee and I'm all done by 11:00

I then have a 3 hour lunch break in a usually empty flat which allows me to crank up the tunes and bust out the moves whilst I prepare something to eat. I'd feel that I'd be lying if I said cooked. My poached eggs have been particularly poor recently. If I'm feeling fancy I'll go out and treat myself to lunch. I think I need to eat more, I think I've lost a bit of weight and it hurts to sit for a while, I need some padding. It's a lot of rice, beans and meat here it seems, think I'm flexing my veggieness a bit too much...

When I do go out at 12 the kids are finishing school, the bars, barzinhos, cafes and restaurants are filled with people out for lunch, by themselves or together, it doesn't matter. Older geezers sit around sharing a large beer, which is bought for the table, that they share around in little glasses. If you want another one, you simply take it out of the container and they will bring you another one.

It's a great system, by the end of the solo beer its warm anyway, particularly here, and even in England I only the chug the bottom because well, I've paid for it and years of peer pressure probably. I love the camaraderie around it and the idea of sharing all the beers for the table and its always cold... depending on who you drink with.

I then continue with my Portuguese lessons, having full conversations about literally anything; politics, psychology, sports, movies, women. I leave feeling like I'm fluent until I go to out into the real world, where everyone speaks a million miles an hour and I'm still very much a gringo. But I'm getting there.

I might catch the game or maybe see somebody for a bit but I usually head back to 'cook' and relax with a film and chocolate before sleeping. Netflix and chill by myself. The imitation game yesterday was so good!

A simple life I know, but the one I needed. I can't however go as slow as the Rio natives, meus dias. I need to have at least something to fill the time for my mental. When the lessons end I'm gunna turn to coding and try to live even more remote! Eventually. I am also gunna learn to dance, as those nights, along with the football, have been amazing.

I went to a samba night last Saturday with the other Portuguese learners and I've gotta say I was hella tired and could nae be arsed, but the energy in the room became infectious. It was a practice for loads of the bands who will perform at Carnaval and everyone was dancing and constantly moving. The feet move a bit fast for me, there is a video of me dancing but I can't post it on here, thank fuck. I prefer the slower sensual forro but still, the bands were amazing and the atmosphere even better, people handing out huge flags for everyone to swing around amidst plenty of professional dancers. I found myself up until 4 still dancing on the way home. I will be attending many more of them.

The weekend was fun but the week routine has been so good for me, I've had many discussions back home with people about how it keeps the mind disciplined along with other benefits. It has a prolonged focus separated by smaller breaks of freedom, by which time, the mind usually requires them. Takes me back to the structure of school. Even working in schools you can see it. Lunchtime is needed and they need to be left alone, mostly. By the end of lunchtime its usually mayhem on the playground. By the end of the day they're all mentally spent.

It's been great for my head, although I can't sit here and tell you it's all figured out. I still rack my brain trying to figure myself out and recently with a few accidental naps I fucked up my sleeping pattern big time. This led to me lying in bed till 2 with an overactive mind which begun a spiral of self centered, anxious, undisciplined thoughts that I couldn't seem to stop. I actually wrote a whole post to it one of the nights I couldn't sleep but that was more for me. Putting it out on paper is something I used to do in forms of raps and now with this and a diary, honestly, it helps immensely. It clears everything out, as if the voice has had his say and is content. So its done its job, the post is still there but it is not representative of my whole being at the moment, just brief interludes.

I'm now doing well to think of it as waves on the beach, if I try and fight these thoughts and suppress it, it is futile and only gets worse, I get hotter and cloudier in the head and they continue. But if I just see these thoughts coming as a tide for example, I imagine myself stepping back on the beach and just watching them come and pass. They surprisingly fade out in time and quicker than expected. They still occur but it's definitely getting better.

This focus is returning and everything's indeed settling. I'm laying down roots, going for drinks and lunches, and joining a football group, but still very much enjoying being alone as well. For now. It gives me time to slowly do as I wish, complete simple tasks and move forward, I definitely feel I'm on the right path, slowly but surely.

Now off for a few shared beers before bed and repeat.

item.title: Dancing
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
Its been 40 days, it does not feel like it, still feel I'm at the beginning, and I hope I am.

I'm going through a process of trying/learning a lot of new things all at once;

  1. Portuguese
  2. the job
  3. coding
  4. meditation
  5. forro

Each one is going pretty well, the routine is helping and I can feel myself taking a step forward with each one, although sometimes one step forward is not enough...

I've been going to a few free trial dance classes with a couple of online English teachers also living here. We began our free classes with forro at about 2 on Saturday, myself donning a pair of flip flops, green shorts and baggy purple vest. Mark, a big Irish dude, opting for the more sensible option of trainers. The camp instructor was very enjoyable and made us feel welcome, helped by the small class size of a dozen or so. It didn't stop the nerves altogether though, with my right leg in particular feeling very tense, not ideal for a rhythmic dance.

It's not particularly complicated at the basic level, just very rhythmic and close. We all joined hands and moved in a line before moving into a circle. By 2 minutes a more experienced, later impatient, lady came between us to help us both out. My flip flops slapping the floor with each step, giving away my poor rhythm. The concentration at times was my downfall, thinking about the steps unsurprisingly put me out of rhythm, but with more practice it became more natural.

I decided to ditch the betraying flip flops and go barefoot at the next possible opportunity. We chose partners like a school disco, with the girls rotating around the room every few minutes. The patriarchy is still alive. stay woke. Although the women were definitely the ones leading and telling me what to do, one filling my confidence by counting for me... Mark seemed to be doing a slightly better job, but as we discussed afterwards, there was a few women who seemed to enjoy helping us and were patient and a few who were less amused.

They were all generally helpful though and the instructor took it at a pace which built it all up into the full dance with turns and all. I can confidently say we got there in the end.

We loved it all and descended on a barzinho with our friend Maddy where we spent the rest of the day drinking, maybe a bit too much, and sharing stories and such.

We enjoyed it so much we decided to head to another free trial of the midweek lessons at the same place, convincing Maddy to join us.

This was a bit different, it appeared there was a massive increase of people and when it started people just started dancing without instruction. madness.

We joined in, and already my first partner began counting... great. We were quickly scouted out as newcomers, again like inception, and guided over to a corner, away from everyone else, with a few others. We then all had a partner each who lead for us, with brief interludes to be taught. This class was very different, a lot more people, a lot more pace and our corner just danced and figured it out ourselves, or didn't figure it out if so the case. There was lots of laughing, lots of missed steps and a few bruised toes for my poor partner. I had not even attempted the flip flops this time.

But towards the end, certain things began to come back, I was doing the spins ite (ish) and the basic steps lol. Mark seemed to widen the gap and was looking good whilst Maddy was holding her own, although she does say its a lot easier with the man leading, but overall an enjoyable night an it will not dissuade me from future dances. Marks already hunted out another few free classes so we'll head to them pretending to be beginners with a bit more experience each time.

And I'm still dancing at lunch times whilst cooking or pre-shower, or whilst teaching (a requirement in one section when the child says pear) and at these times I can honestly tell you I'm a fantastic dancer...

But I'm actually finding a lot of rhythm and flow in my other aspects of life so I'll take that, if not the dancefloor.

I've also attached a page called soundtrack for a playlist of these that my dad's made, or the songs I'm listening to. Enjoy

item.title: Move Along
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
Sunday morning, election day here, or at least the first round of voting.

After watching the UFC fight last night at a place literally called 'fight bar' drinking caipirinhas (terrible things) I awoke with a stonking headache just in time to escort Jose to the polls to witness their democracy in action. I originally took a camera and intended to document it, but with the big burly security guards stood next to signs saying no cameras, I thought better of it. He voted in a country club in Ipanema of where he used to live and gives the security guy a warm handshake.

He tells me he sees this guy only every 4 years but they greet each other as if they are very good friends who share a treasured history. I loved this relationship they shared of only interacting when the elections come around yet both enjoy seeing each other, even for a brief moment.

Standing around waiting, and I was waiting a long time, was very enjoyable, the hall was filled with people, all with different opinions on how the country should be run, lots of them donning Brazil shirts and stickers of their favoured candidates. Crazy and divided as it's been, and will continue to be, I loved just thinking about democracy and how every one can have their say. As the quote says...

I do not agree with what you have to say, but I'll defend to the death your right to say it.

- Evelyn Beatrice Hall

It really is a great thing. Which is why its important to vote, and why its scary that Bolsonaro will get in. He constantly sympathises with the torturous dictatorship they had here in the 60s, 70s and 80s and has said before he wants to go back to one, although he has since backtracked. Jose's sister was going to vote for Bolsonaro until on the way her thoughts turned to how great it is she can vote before realising that to vote for him is against the very thing which allows you to do so.

The results came in last night, and he just missed out on the majority, reaching 46% which means a second round against the left candidate who received 29% of votes. However as discussed before he is being mostly rejected due to his party's recent corruption, another protest vote to spite their face. Lots of people are rejecting Bolsonaro aswell, but he will most likely get the 5 percent he needs to become the new leader.

This topped off a Sunday which actually had me feeling pretty low anyway and for the first time here I was feeling pretty lonely, with thoughts about coming home. It was a culmination of a few things, the alcohol from last night, the fact my Portuguese progress seems to have stagnated, a more confrontational football game and the prospect of a military dictatorship. But I was very sensitive to even the slightest thing, which in turn lead to me getting frustrated with myself for being sensitive and giving myself a hard time. I thought of it as a long wave and settled into bed to watch Guardians of the Galaxy in Portuguese. Its funny, I could understand Groot more than the others. At times like this you just gotta go to bed, accept defeat on the day and pick yourself up again in the morning ready to start again and move forward.

Well the morning seemed to have only gotten worse. I woke up at half 5 to find the internet and the source of my livelihood was down. Upon resetting there was nothing. So back up plan is to use my phones data. Ah. I only had 60p credit left, so I had to wait for the shops to open to get some more before returning sharpish ready to teach. Worst of all we also had run out of coffee for the flat and in my cafuffle I dropped the rest of my cake, a breakfast staple here, on the floor. But I struggled through the morning and made all my classes with no glitches and left the room taking a deep breath.

Out there I encountered 2 of my room mates discussing the internet which appears to be down in the whole region as well as the TV and wont be on till later today, so I'm writing this draft in notepad. We sat and laughed, blaming everything that was going wrong on Bolsanaro basically being in power as Jose munched on a butter sandwich. This morning being a precursor of the next 4 years.

I needed that, laughing as everything was going wrong around me and taking myself less seriously, and as the day drew on I began to feel a lot better, finding a second wind and motivation to continue, feeling the waves washing back out to shore.

item.title: Don't Let Me Be Misunderstood
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
First things first, I've found the best coffee shop situated a mere 2 minute walk away from my house and that is where I will now be writing most of my posts. Like a true remote worker.

It's dead cheap, the coffees come with a truffle and the cookies melt in the middle. On top of this and perhaps more important is the fact its open till 21:30 on weekdays and sells beer at the equivalent to Â£1.50. It's decor suggest Scandinavian but with brighter lighting, positive music and browner people. A hexagonal logo which appears around the cafe tessellates nicely as tables and on the walls something which appeals to my sometimes logical mind.

Earlier today whilst indulging in said truffles and coffee I arranged a hefty refund for my flight to Argentina as I will stay here hopefully for another 4 months. This put me in a mood I can only describe as blissful. I usually attribute this mood to when all my senses are positively stimulated and I have many moments that are stored as snapshot memories that fill these criteria, including; one in Copenhagen, many atop mountains, a couple in the sea but most in good company with the usual backdrop of a bar.

The best way to describe how I was feeling is just to leave this here...

This guy can express how I felt or can feel and actually I am finding myself dancing around lot, having discovered quite a lot of good music whilst being here. But I'm pretty sure I don't look as good. In fact now we can view our online lessons at any time we desire and I'm certain I don't.

Earlier in the week however I did not feel so good. I spent Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday pretty much in the house besides a few supermarket visits. This was a mistake. At the time I never really felt like I needed to leave. I could cook and save money and I spent lots of time coding and learning Portuguese. The evenings I had the NBA.

I was in a bit of a conflict with myself, I mean... I'm here to live, not just be a tourist. I cant go out and party every night, eat out and see everything like I'm travelling. But even at home just staying in can drive a person mental and I am here in Rio, I do need to do a bit more or it will past me by. So for the weekends at least I'm gunna try and make sure I do more sightseeing kinda things and I'm gunna get out the house every day even if it's just to the cafe. Overall it was just too much time with myself and as most people know, too much time with me can get annoying. lol. That's a joke, LAUGH. But I can get myself down a bit and convince myself I'm not very good or good at anything, or that nobody actually likes me. Which is of course absurd.

So on Thursday we went to go see Venom and even something simple like heading to the cinema made me feel a million times better. And everyone hating on Venom, you're wrong, which is fine, you're allowed to be wrong, but still...you're wrong.

I loved it. Fun, easy, Venom's a bit of a dude and it fits in with the narrative of the 2 systems, the inner battle of the ego and the id which has appeared in a lot of art I'm consuming recently. Ok, in us it may not be as intense as an alien wanting to eat peoples heads off (in most of us) but the idea came from somewhere right and the more I talk to people about these sort of things, the more I hear the words "I get that".

One of my favourite things to hear, it causes a strong connection and a fantastic feeling of being understood.

It helps me not to pathologise things that I think and feel, and convince myself I'm crazy when its completely normal. So thanks Eddie/Venom, you get it, and you helped me accept this side of me rather than fighting against it, I definitely feel more at one. He's also a Warriors fan. My guy.

This stems to all art, it can be used to express things which can otherwise be hard to do. Through painting, writing, characters and in my opinion the most powerful, Music.

To hear somebody else describing the emotion you are feeling better than you can articulate it yourself is an amazing feeling. You not only feel understood but also understand better. Kid Cudi was always great for me, amongst others but I'm sure we all have our artists. Even the notes on a piano or a harp can strike a chord (completely intended) with how we feel and I just think that's an amazing social phenomenon. Where would we be without music, or other forms of art.

But ye, lesson learned, get out of the house, don't stay trapped inside your own house and your own head. Be social. Have fun.

I found a bar that shows basketball also 2 minutes in the opposite direction to the cafe so I'm pretty set. But as I sit here, about to read my second book this week and off to the beach and a beer festival thing this eve, I'm content, with both myself and how everything is going.

I struggled to decide which version is better so here's both. You decide.

item.title: Work Out
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
It was a fantastic weekend last weekend, I was riding a high, at one point on Saturday exploring a new area, closing my eyes as I and the song hit a high note simultaneously.

Later on physically heading up, but to a pretty cool coffee festival with an even better view, before descending to watch Flamengo in a lil' pizzeria. At first it seemed quiet for such a big game, but in Brazilian fashion, many of them were just late to the party, including the players. The game not being much of a spectacle until the 80th minute when it exploded into life, with chance after chance resulting in a 1-1. Flamengo still 4 points adrift with 7 games to go.

We continued drinking into the night at a small bar/club next door called comuna which guessing by its inhabitants (and obvious Latin root) means commune or for the communists. A very left-wing atmosphere was building with chants of ele nÃ£o occurring as well as many homosexual displays. Generally they are so much more open to gay people or trans people and I'm becoming so much more to accustomed to it. Its not that I ever felt uncomfortable back home, it was just more noticeable due to a lack of exposure. Here, its way more common to see two gay lovers holding hands or kissing on the benches as well as an increase in the amount of trans people. Its so much more welcoming.

After a few beers the Portuguese flowed a lil' easier and I was having some great conversations with many people who humored me, helped me and understood me. I did wonder if we would be as welcoming to someone speaking very broken English to us in a club, hmmmm... I left when I could no longer speak in Portuguese. I still had enough to speak English, just about. I returned feeling great and awoke with no real hangover, things going swimmingly.

But what goes up must go down, as I found when returned Sunday night, after a frustrating game of football. As before, there were 3 common denominators, the football performance, the excessive alcohol the night before and the voting of the natives. This time for the real presidency and their far right candidate, who indeed won.

What a picture.

It really depicts the feelings of many Brazilians here, but unfortunately not the majority and this is the democracy in action that I declared my love for one month back. The return home from the football was sound-tracked by a melody of car horns, cheers and 'fireworks'. Although it should be noted I did not SEE any fireworks... In contrast I did see several people in tears. This was as divided as the rest of them.

For myself and some people I've spoke to it's the attitude he projects and validates towards those in the minorities or those more vulnerable. A common theme throughout the world at the moment, a world which could also come under further threat from him.

After all us 'flexitarians' and actual vegans did to try and rebel against the agriculture in places such as the amazon, it seems it may be futile. If he can implement his previous promises, he will cultivate indigenous and protected land for the use of agriculture, mining and big businesses, tearing down the rainforest.

Voices abroad and myself included, looking from the outside with no reference to previous Brazilian politics, can't believe they've chosen this tyrant. But speaking with taxi drivers, friends and locals alike, the rejection for the opposition is much higher than the hatred of Bolsonaro. Many people trying to explain to me how PT have been in power for too long (16 years) and within the last 8 years; violence is rising, the economy falling and their previous 'saviour' Lula is now tainted with the very corruption that Bolsonaro promises to rid. They are hurt. They want a change. Although I'm not sure this is the answer.

Many articles have been claiming fake news decided things and they will no doubt have had some influence but this was always coming, they will not vote for the previous party. It was more about rejection than support for Bolsonaro with 30% who were registered to vote deciding not or voting blank, 42 million people. If the PT faithful hadn't boosted themselves into the 2nd round, another candidate would have definitely had a better chance at toppling Bolsonaro. Alas... here we are.

Already their economy has taken a turn due to the belief in him throughout business circles. Which means bad news for me. Being paid in dollars I have taken a pay cut.

Told you he was a bastard.

This month I was meant to be doing a bit better and have a bit of breathing room but now that's fucked it. I've had to pick up a side hustle and do more hours of work than 15 a week. Modern Slavery.

For real though its a pretty cool tutoring job online, where whilst I'm doing my own shit, people ring me for as long as they like, just to have a chat. The past 2 days I've earned $40 talking to an 18 year old Saudi about FIFA, a Korean lady about the work ethic in their culture, and a guy in Italy about firmware and software. I'm hearing lots of different points of views and actually getting a lot out of it as well as cash money. God bless the empire.

Still though, with the real (the currency) rising, if it continues, I will be priced out of Brazil. I'm not worried though cause looking around it seems any other South American country will be cheaper and I'll be able learn another culture and another language. So come February I will head down South I think, to Uruguay or Argentina before settling in a country of my choosing, possibly Colombia, possibly Peru, possibly not Venezuela. My options are pretty open though and I feel very positive. I will miss carnaval but I'm assured January has a sufficient amount of pre-carnaval street parties to soften the blow and new years will be amazing. I also plan to be in SA next year so I can always return.

So after the fall of Sunday, the next few days flip flopped a bit, with difficulty sleeping being the consequence of blissful naps, good coffee and overthinking.

One of the problems being that working at home or on the move can be lonesome, with little opportunity to meet people. I'm starting to feel good about myself again but I could use a lil' love. My tinder game is not strong, my Portuguese weaker and usually my relationships have been through meeting friends of friends or working with people, where it has just happened, developing with ease and beauty. But here I find little opportunity to recreate it and in the cruel paradox, the more you try to look for it, the harder it becomes to find.

I have been reluctant to enter into relationships of late, part in due to my instability of position and part due to previous experience of such instances. This has had a hangover which lead to reluctance for quite a while, but I have learnt a lot and am more open to the fluidity of future plans and going with how you feel. I do miss being in love. I know its the greatest feeling and will bring me the most happiness, yet there's a part of me holding back from it, telling myself I still have more to do. Seeing families and friends around me, I know the grass is not just greener, but always green.

This is my favourite verse of all time.

But I have to take the rough with the smooth, I love the freedom it gives me and I know I'll have plenty of time for that, right now I can enjoy the other things, while I wait. And I still find small pockets of friendship. I'm really enjoying the evenings watching the Brazilian soap and sharing Brigadeiro (essentially a bowl of half melted chocolate) Baconzitos (an absurdly addictive crisp) and Guarana (the angels juice). And Basketball.

These things have a habit of coming along at a good time, when everything is going right and it feels good, so I'm not gunna rush things, it will all work out when its supposed to. I just have to have faith and patience.

Double Chance.

item.title: Let Me Take You To Rio
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
Been a busy few weeks. I've fallen behind on life; this, my own diary, coding and Duolingo. Works been annoying, I've read zero books and I have no idea whats going on in the soap.

But I have done many new things and seen more parts of the city than I have in the previous 3 months and been with great company all the while. I think its been important to do and great fun. But its also taken a lot of energy out of me.

There's quite a lot to write about and so to integrate with my coding practice, I've incorporated some shortcuts. Please click below to jump to different days to read about them. If you only fancy a couple, I recommend both the Friday's, they were definite highlights and I understand why such incredible artists such as the Cure and Rebecca Black have made songs about them. If you fancy the long haul or like continuity, keep on scrolling baby!

Enjoy


Thursday    Friday   Saturday   Sunday    Monday   Midweek   Friday

Thursday


As a few friends of friends arrived the week before, it took till Thursday to finally meet. Now when people ask me to show them around Rio, the truth is, I don't really know where to take them. They probably don't want to see the basketball bar or the cheap place for food round the corner. And when it comes to the weekend, having been so far disappointed by the nightlife in Lapa, I don't really know where to take them. Besides the beaches.

But it helps when they have an idea, I can take you where you want, alongside my secret weapon of the Brazilian housemate who used to work in tourism, doing exactly that. Showing gems to myself as well as friends in the city.

So the girls Lucy and Lauren, a connection through the family of Ameet's girlfriend, eventually arrived and I joined them to Sugarloaf mountain. Damn it was expensive. I tried to speak to the ticketeers (surely that's a word) and claim a residents discount in my best PortuguÃªs. I didn't get it but the full fee was worth it to go up there, at least once.

When you come to Rio all the advice is to do everything at either sunset or sunrise to get the best experience. Everything. We got many great pictures including my first creep of a couple. They were looking at each other so lovingly and happily that I had to, just missing the kiss. When I showed the girls, Lauren had told me how much she had liked it when someone had sent her the picture, and as a way of feeling less creepy I showed them. They loved it and were very appreciative. And they had brought tinnies up to the top. Legends. Northern Irish. Who very strangely turned out to be friends with Mark!

So we saw the sun go down and the lights go up, before making our way down into Botafogo for some drinks in the bars. We spent the night drinking in a row of bars in which everyone is sat in the street, on chairs I should add. One of my favourite things to do here. But with the night fast approaching, work tomorrow and more importantly the Warriors on, I made my way to the basketball bar of which the girls had actually wanted to join. Something I've found that people generally do if you just do you. Unfortunately though it was not on so we had a lil' nightcap before heading off home.

back to top 

Friday

The next day I called on my Brazilian weapon (Jose) (nothing else) to show them (us) around Leme Rock at the end of Copacabana beach

We saw Monkeys.

I don't think I've ever seen monkeys unless in a zoo and I loved every second. They were inquisitive and curious little monkeys climbing down electricity poles and trees to say hello. Or at least to see what was going on. They would stay calm, staring at us as we stared back at them. We had no food but continued to try to offer them pieces of grass or whatever we could find lying around. It was hard to continue, wanting to stay with them/become one. An old feeling I used to have in university. But we trekked up, seeing again some beautiful views of Rio from a different angle.

I returned after a quick rum and coke with the girls atop the hotel roof, back to nap and get ready for the night out. In Lapa. Lauren had gone and Lucy wanted to go see some samba so I consulted my contacts and received a long list of places. With one sticking out in both of the lists I was sent. Carioca da Gema.

After napping, I didn't feel like going out. I never do. It took a long time to get in the mood, secretly hoping that she too did not want to. But I'm glad again that she did. So we hit up the famous lapa steps that Pharrell and Snoop once graced before meeting Mark and his singer girl, Thays, for a few drinks. This led to an impromptu set from her and her mandolin playing friend in the street, of many classic Brazilian songs, including Mais Que Nada. A few people came over to watch and give their compliments. It was a lovely moment, and on that note, we hit up the samba bar for more.

Now before, I have had a few alright nights in Lapa with one in particular which I enjoyed. But this bar has completely changed my opinion on the place. Upon entering, with our drink still in hand, we made our way to the stage amongst of crowd of mostly middle aged people. We looked the youngest there by quite a margin. The decor, small stage and the buzz surrounding the place, reminded me of New Orleans, holding the title for my favourite place in the world. But now I'm reconsidering.

We stood and watched the artists take the stage and a group of 6, all donning a different instrument, began to play, each exhibiting different personalities and characteristics. We watched a few people around us dancing and as I have done before, we decided to just give it a go. Me using a very slight bit of forro knowledge to lead. Over our shoulders was a couple, who to me, represented Brazilians perfectly.

Both around their 30's, I would guess, beautifully brown, slim. Him in a football jersey, her in a dress just shy of her knees, coloured with a bright background behind blue birds. They moved around swiftly but calmly, moving closer and further apart in time with the music and sharing intimate kisses. Their rhythm was incredible, as was their chemistry. In that moment for those two I'm sure nobody else was around.

But we were, and we attempted many of the same moves and although we may not have nailed them, we had a great night trying. There's something about the dance clubs here, its much more intimate and I for one am a fan.

So we danced into the night, really being drawn along with the atmosphere of the place and the tone of the music, before reconvening for the beach the next day.

back to top 

Saturday

Spending the whole day at the beach drinking  beers and caipirinhas, haggling vendors, and taking dips. Becoming slowly more drunk before the sun caught up with us. Lucy had made a new facebook friend in the lady selling cheese; she was particularly lovely with a memorable voice that was very high. I imagine she had a fantastic laugh. We took our drunken tomfoolery to the streets of Ipanema, having one more nightcap before using our towels as weapons/accessories as we made our way back through the streets and eventually the cab.

back to top 

Sunday

I then traded her in (lol) for my friend Hanisah, of which we started as I had left off, catching up over a few beers and caipirinhas before hitting up the beach for what was day 2. A great start to Rio for her I'm sure with great weather, better views and topping up the tan before she's even begun. Important for those holiday pics. So we spent the day lounging, swimming, drinking and the like. By 2 o'clock, having already had a caipirinha and a few beers I felt a peak of emotion which was almost too intense and it broke me, I had to take a while to calm myself and chill out. Which we did on another beach amongst friends.

But the weekend, the sun and the drinking had caught up on me and I was beginning to struggle by Sunday night, making, what I felt was a mess of introducing her to Mark and Thays. Trying to get everyone involved with the languages and everything, appeared too much for me in this state and I found the whole thing more awkward than I'm assured it was. So we scuttled away to the hostel and Hanisah kindly made me dinner before sending me home.

back to top 

Monday

Now on Monday I pulled out my weapon again (stop it) and we headed to another of Snoop and Pharrell's spots in the city in Parque Lage. A historic mansion with columns surrounding a swimming pool in the centre that is not for swimming. A beautiful spot surrounded by beautiful gardens and jungle like foliage that provides a walk up to the Christ. It's an amazing place that's actually an art college, as if it needed to be any cooler, with people around painting on large sheets or filling classrooms. This may be a future spot for blog writing. It felt comforting, even in the rain. Maybe even more in the rain.

Now when it rains you could be excused for thinking that Rio is only for tourists and service people as the Cariocas retreat in and choose not to leave their house. This is especially true for Jose who tells me as the phrase goes "eu sou feito de aÃ§Ãºcar" - I am made of sugar. As he looked fearfully out the window, I convinced him to take us and he did a great job showing us around lil' caves and other parts of the jungleness we surely wouldn't have wondered to.

We saw more monkeys. Further away this time but feasting on a jackfruit together.

back to top 

Midweek

The busyness and heavyness of the weekendness had taken its toll on me as I fell ill the next day and spent the next few days with a painful throat for swallowing, paired with fevers. But don't feel bad for me, I learnt a lot of PortuguÃªs through watching films, including a few cartoons of which Hanisah joined me in her hungover state. And I was back ok by the Friday. Always seems to be the way...

back to top 

Friday

In a gamble, I agreed to go do the Dois IrmÃ£os hike for what was another high up view of Rio for what was yes, another sunset. I wasn't sure about how I would be feeling but armed with my magical pills (that I bought from the pharmacy) and a can do attitude I attempted the hike. Now many people, mostly Maddy, had tried to get me to do it, including one previous failed attempt with hostelis, but truth be told I couldnae be arsed on many occasions. Seemed like a lot of effort but I knew I had to do it at some point and with Hani being here it was a good time to concede. Sorry Maddy.

But I was fucking right, it was fucking effort.

So I went to meet Hani at the secluded beach on Sao Conrado, of which she positioned herself as far as humanly possible to the side that the metro wasn't. Long. But the beach was beautiful and very empty, leaving us to dip and relax, able to leave our bags unattended and having our own space.

I didn't really think things through/no-one had warned me/everyone had told me the walk up is easy. So I was only donning a pair of flip flops, worn ones at that, as we made our way up.

Moto-taxiing up to the football field in the favela where the trek began was an enjoyable start. My geezer cackling as he rode past people, pretending to lasso other drivers in front before surging forward. The football field was inhabited by children, no older than 5, being coached in a similar style I had applied when coaching Americans of the same age. Shouting, what I imagine was, TURN AROUND! TURN! STOP! TURN!, KICK!, to stop them from running off the pitch. Although I used to used animals as instructions that I had already primed (For more coaching tips, pm me). Also the football pitch was just turf in terrible condition with many areas of concrete showing underneath. But the fundamentals were the same, from the Favelas to Silicon Valley. Humans.

We began our trek, easily enough, following the track, taking pictures of butterflies and peeking at views through the bushes, each view becoming nicer and nicer the higher we climbed. But the higher we climbed, the steeper it got. The steeper it got, the more difficult it became to climb and, the more my footwear began to let me down... Now the only advice we had had was, do it at sunset/sunrise. Shock. And to follow the beaten track. No signs or anything to help but I mean... this thing just would not stop. The trees in front always hiding how far we really had to go. About 7 hours in (probably 30 minutes) we ran into a few Brazilians on the way down. I pleadingly asked them if we were near the top to which they responded about 20 minutes. I genuinely thought they were having me on, and would not accept it. And they were wrong, it was another 3 hours (they were right). So we plodded on, involving lots of chit chats and having to go barefoot for a large remainder of the journey. I also forgot about water, but thankfully Hanisah had got some so we rationed on the way.

We made it, not before the clouds had blotted out the sun and a chance at sunset, but we made it. It was empty and the views were still incredible. I've started to develop a pretty good 3D aerial image of Rio by now and have seen it from 4 different vantage points and the one thing that always pops into my mind and had popped into Hanisah's is that "which crazy bastard's idea was it to build a city here?" amongst all the high rise mounds and the lagoon, it does not seem feasible. They shouldn't really have attempted it, the city sprawls around each mound an favelas begin to rise up what looks, and I quote 'prehistoric' hills.

But I'm very glad they did as this is fast becoming my favourite place in the world, the vast entertainment across the city matched with a relaxed nature. The stunning views both high and low and the culture of dance, football and pure enjoyment. I'm beginning to love samba more and more with each song and it really just matches the feel of the city.

As we began our descent, in perfect timing, the rain began to come as the nighttime began to roll in. Just perfect. For a mere second I thought god exists, and he was laughing at us or maybe I had brought on the rain with my constant, although mostly joking, negativity towards the situation. We made our way down with music and still joking around, I actually enjoyed the dark descent through the jungle more. With no shoes and a drop of rain, it felt more adventurous and just silly. Stopping on occasions to look at the favela opposite, lit up like fireflies, and to try and snap the lightning in the distance.

As time began to long out again, Hanisah began to get on at me to hurry up. Now unless you are Mowgli or Tarzan or have done this before then you can complain, but its not fucking easy. Its doable and better than flip flops but I wasn't fast. I dunno how those guys did it. Eventually we made our way down, drinking atop the favela bar to take in a few more views before heading down for a well earned beer, or 4, in the streets of Botafogo amongst friends. A brilliant end to what was a great day.

back to top 

Conclusion

On Saturday we headed up Santa Teresa and walked around enjoying ourselves up there and walking up and down the Lapa steps. But for now I've rambled enough and I'm sure you're as tired as I am, and I will be spending more time up there in the next few months.

It has been a long break from writing for me and there is a lot I wanted to get, down, thanks if you are still reading. I don't wish to take this long again but I was very busy and although I've really enjoyed it, I welcome the break. In my moments to relax I didn't get the inspiration to write, choosing to chill out by watching movies or napping. This means I also hadn't got to share many of my thoughts and feelings that I'd had, as they have now gone, but don't fear, I'll spread my pearls of wisdom plenty in future posts I'm sure.

For now Hanisah has headed for Salvador, Bahia for a few days of which I am very jealous and I will spend the week relaxing, reading, coding and not drinking. She will return for one more night of samba on Friday before I send her back off to you guys back home.

item.title: Mountain to Move
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
So everybody's gone,

I don't know what I did or said but everyone has left or is leaving.

Within 24 hours, Maddy, Leandro (one of my housemates) and Hanisah all left for England. Mark left for a week but will follow back home for a longer period not 7 days from now and another of my housemates will leave at the same time.

But don't cry for me, avid readers. I've actually got shit to do and money to save. This is probably a good thing in actuality (that's a great word isn't it).

But before Hani went, either side of her trip to Salvador, we got to do a few more touristy and fun things including a couple of beach days. On the Saturday, which I began to mention, was a day in which we explored around Santa Teresa, rode the tram over the famous Lapa arches and walked up and down the Lapa steps.

Now the Lapa arches are less impressive knowing what goes on underneath, homeless gatherings by day and drunken debauchery by night. But the steps are quite a spectacle both day and night. By day its full of tourists taking pictures and admiring the many tiles, of which are changed all the while. It is an ongoing art project by Selaron who accepts tiles sent to him, and adds many at different points in the year. I'm thinking of getting Bubbenhall up there, to rival the many American states, particularly Florida. But by night it becomes a hangout for people to drink and smoke whilst casually conversing. I've had many a good conversation sat on the Lapa steps and the Friday night just gone did not disappoint either. I'll always see it as I did then, or the week before, not as the tourist trap it could be seen as in the day. It's a good atmosphere for sure, made even better no doubt by the cheap Caipirinha sellers at the bottom.

This would be Hani's last night, so we went to samba at Carioca de Gema. Similar band as before but this time the place appeared to be a bit more crowded. We still attempted to get a lil' dance in and enjoyed the music but left considerably early for what we would've done years before.

The uber appeared to be a cloud that drifted us home. I don't know what we'd done in the day but my legs were feeling it and Hanisah was tired from her late flight. We spoke of our age and how great it feels to go home early now compared to previous years. As we made it home, I ran straight to my comfy clothes as we joined Jose, who is always up, to watch a stupid joke show while Hanisah ate cereal and I munched on crisps and drank pop. Ah Adulthood

I just don't care as much as I used to. I'd rather sit and have a bottle of wine and chat than go out into a party atmosphere. To a point I think I've always preferred it, but maybe it's just growing up.

( So raging, just scrolled through all my tweets to go quote myself from circa 2012 on this topic and it was a retweet. Also terribly embarrassed by hundreds of my other previous tweets. )

Anywho we rose fairly fresh for Hani's last day and decided to have a nice lunch to leave. It became an absolute battle and really showcased our differences in preference. Each place she seemed to like specialised in pretentious fish dishes, in which, based on price, have been boiled in bottled water and comes with immortality. I almost considered paying Â£10 for some salad as it was her last day but I just couldn't do it. Particularly as this cluttered French looking restaurant had a great view of a modern looking pizza bar with plenty of space. I really couldn't. So we compromised on the first restaurant we went to and had some Picanha, a specialty here or simply put very rare steak marinated in I'm guessing a tub of salt and it was actually a good compromise as we were both very happy/full as we napped on the beach.

It was a shame as she claimed that the fancy French (two words of which I hold negative connotations) place was her perfect restaurant and equally the pizza bar, two of the greatest things we as humans have created, looked like mine. At one point we joked about ordering from separate sides and waving to each other. I wasn't joking.

She claimed my place had no soul. I said we'd create the soul.

I claimed her place was up itself, she said it was just good quality.

She claimed I have a bland palette, she might have a point.

In fact since I've been here, I've become very disinterested in food, even more so, seeing it mainly as fuel to live. I wouldn't say Brazil has the best cuisine. Ok, the barbecue is pretty good and the picanha might be one of the greatest things, but its all just meat, rice and beans at the end of the day and a lot of the time, over seasoned with salt. With it being brought into the collective consciousness that over consumption of meat has negative effects on the environment and now, with it being more important than ever, it leaves me in a sticky situation which gives me a lot of cognitive dissonance. Being in Brazil, where it literally cuts down the rainforest is an even bigger problem and with their guy about to open it to farming and business again, it really could fuck things up. So now we're really in a pickle.

I've grown bored of my own cooking, due to not being able to afford good ingredients and choosing instead to go round the corner to a guy who cooks chicken, beans and rice with a slight variation each day for a very low price. Its economical and I can't tell you how happy I get when I only have to wash up a plate. I'm tempted to buy 2 of his meals a day and just have cereal in the morning. I feel like one day I'll get into cooking like my dad, but for now this guy'll do and the one contribution I feel I'm making to the world is not eating beef.

Except for Saturday.

And Sunday.

But that's not my fault guys, one of our football crew was leaving so we had a little tournament and some barbecue to finish. the guy even paying for a free bar! What could I do. He brought a bottle of gin, for player of the tournament and to tell the truth I felt a little robbed. Although bottling (lol, not intended this time) it in the final, I thought I had a big influence on the games and banged in a few decent goals.

Despite the big head and Kanye like self-buildupness, there was no award interruption from me and I joined in the festivities to the maximum.

It was great fun, one of the first really social things I've experienced with the group, talking to many people I'd had little interaction with before, speaking portuguese with Argentinians, nostalgia with Brits and mentalities with a German lad, Chris. I hope we do this on the regular.

We discussed the idea of work ethic between the German's, the English and the Brazilians and in my favourite idea of the spectrum it fell, unsurprisingly, a lil' something like this.

Brazil        Me       England     Germany

0 --------------------------------------------- 1

Although it should be noted I've been working off the clock (is that a phrase) recently. Not for money, but on my coding. I've been learning javascript which is essentially when you can start doing fun shit.

html is like building the building

css is painting it and adding the furniture

and javascript is blowing up the windows, hiding living things in walls and cupboards and making the sofa float around the room following you.

It feels like I've got a new toy and I'm figuring out all the settings, just like I used to with other peoples phones. And there is a lot.

It actually doesn't feel like work at all. I'm spending about 5 hours a day on it, always wanting to know more. This was a path I had wanted to follow in sixth form but gave way to other's advice and dropped it for yes, film studies, that important subject, just to get me to uni, to then get a psychology degree... But I've opened it back up and am excited to follow down it.

Back home some of the clearest I was, was mid puzzle. Nothing was around me, I was focused on the logic, it took up all of my thought. And now this is like one big ongoing puzzle. As I walk down the street, my brain turns to how to get that box to give me all that data. Right now I'm stuck, but I'm enjoying that that stays in my thought.

The only thing that distracts me and tbf it does quite often, is the possibility of the future. Quite often, mid project, I have to bring myself back because I'm away thinking of the future, the things I'll be able to do, the places I could go if remote and the money I could make. I do have to bring myself back down and remind myself I'll have to actually learn it before I can do it, I guess I'm more of a dreamer than a doer but I feel enlivened by it. It actually gives me energy.

Anyway, the last few weeks felt like a nice lil' holiday but I'm getting back into my actual life now, watching basketball bi-nightly, alongside the soap and looking forward to Soccer Saturdays, it appears this month will be a lot like this. And the next one, but I have absolutely no qualms with that. I've got a lot of time and it's time to get back on the coding and the Portuguese.
