item.title: Wanna Be Cool
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
I am a breaker of things

Always have been, things break around me and this month, this has made itself apparent again. No matter where I am, I will break things.

I should take care more really, but even when I really try to, shit happens.

So heres a list of the things I can think of in the past 2 weeks.

  1. the toastie maker, accidentally toasted the wire, cue a few sparks and the end to my cheese toasties. Luckily the only guy who also uses it is in England visiting his girlfriend so I have time to fix (buy a new one) it.
  2. My camera, actually gutted about this one, I love this thing, was a present before i left to America and had to be fixed out there, but since then in particular I have been careful with it. But the lens is now not coming out, so will need to look into that.
  3. My phone, it's been cracked for a while. the end was near, although it didn't occur how I expected it to.
  4. Between the beginning and end of this post, my blinds.

But let me take you back, I left you with the idea that my coding was flying and I would be creating the next facebook in no time.

What a difference a day makes. The Friday when I last posted was spent struggling and not understanding well. I had burnt myself out and was putting too much pressure on myself. Work has not been fruitful recently and I desperately want to be able to make money doing something I enjoy, so I was trying to bust through it, to get somewhere fast. Bad idea.

I had a real moment of angst about the future for a short while. A moment where my eyelids narrowed and my inner monologue may have sounded a bit like this

ughhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh

In that moment I also broke myself, but I sorted it with a nap and the decision to slow down, it will happen over time. I made the decision to learn it down in South America, because I have time. So I will use it and I then spent the evening, hanging out at home and watching basketball.

Now what I have been trying to make is a website to give me football stats to help me break the bookies. Even if the maths doesn't help, the practice will. The maths has a 1-0 start with a nice win of Â£50 and I left for the botanical gardens feeling pretty chilled again. 1-1 if you count both bets (which I don't). So I left for the botanical gardens with a smile on my face.

This is where I discovered the fault in my camera, so unfortunately I cannot share any pictures, which is a shame cause there were some beautiful birds and some interesting plants. And bees without stings! I still didn't get too close, although now I think about it, I don't know why.

So as I wandered around the gardens without my camera and a phone without data, I thought this would be great, no connection to the world, just in the moment, seeing whats around me. Lost in nature. Unfortunately this was not the case. I spent a lot of it thinking about life, my life and trying to figure myself out. Whilst also giving myself a hard time over things from small things ages ago and over the fact I wasn't in the moment whilst being there and for being narcissistic and thinking of myself.

I did have a few happy distractions, mostly by the birds and the amazonian section, but overall, I think I probably saw more of the path than the surroundings. Sad but true.

Sometimes these thoughts can spiral down and continue, other times I stop myself and bring myself back into the world, this time I spiraled out of it though, feeling I am beginning to internalize something that I know and tell myself all the time, but in practice it's not always so easy.

Essentially, it breaks down to being yourself and not caring about others opinions. I know myself and I love myself and I should be myself but sometimes I find it difficult to actually put this into action. Not always, mind.

I've found I've acted differently at times in my life in order to be liked and accepted, a pretty human feeling, and stopped being me or doing me things, being more normal in order to achieve this.

But that's not really me, I'm acting on, not even necessarily the opinions of others, but sometimes my perceived opinions that others have or might have and find myself analyzing my own behaviour all the while. Self-consciousness.

In reality, I don't know and I shouldn't care what they are thinking. It's not even my right to know, it's their thoughts and it should make no difference to me. But sometimes it does. When I catch myself doing this now, I can start to imagine that person's head as an old fuzzy TV screen that I can't see and that usually flips me back.

I've always respected those who are unapologetically themselves and who don't care.

Its much more important to be yourself because then people will actually like you, for you. Flaws and quirks and all. Or not. Either way.

That's true acceptance.

Now this is one part of this, some time away to think about things like this, figure out whats going on in me and to be me. For better or worse I do think these things and other thoughts trying to figure out life, maybe too much sometimes, but I also enjoy asking why and trying to figure out things such as the world, social behaviours and the self. I would rather that, than just ignore it. I will always take the red pill.

Another part is to decide what I wanna do, it's been a toss up between a coder/programmer and a teacher. P.E teacher most likely. And it still swings, I do enjoy the coding but then films like Coach Carter and Freedom Writers, which I watched Monday night, really help convince me that teaching is such a good force in the world. Although sometimes I think fuck it and I should go work on helping the environment cause lord knows that needs the help.

The last 2 parts and the most important is to learn about the languages and cultures down here, and enjoy myself. I am in Brazil after all.

After I've shared with you my honest, slightly negative thoughts and feelings in the day, I can share the same of a much more positive nature;

I felt unbelievably calmer once returning home. The thoughts stopped, the narcissism finished and I looked forward to the night, spending it with Mark and his girlfriend, Thays, at a night celebrating culture from another state, her state. There I was completely out of my own head and in the moment, with zero effort. We enjoyed a few drinks and this time I broke a few hearts on the dancefloor prancing around in the traditional skirt, emulating the ladies who danced alongside me.

We consumed a few more beverages in our favourite barzinho nearby before hitting up a samba night in a alleyway. These nights are always fantastic, everybody is enjoying themselves and dancing along, drinking in the streets. In fact we revisited this spot last night as Thays was singing there. Before we even made it, we stumbled upon a large samba band performing nearby in a street adjacent to many bars.

Most likely practicing for carnaval, this is set to become more and more common, being told that pre-carnaval and the summer months are just street parties with music and costumes, so we sat down and enjoyed good conversation, beer and music before watching Thays sing and attempting to dance with the Brazilians.

Now something weird that's been happening here is I've become very broody. I know that having children will be the greatest happiness and there's time for that, but I've been feeling it recently and feel I could settle at some point in the near future.

One of the street vendors on Saturday had brought her children along, including her 4 months old child which she let me hold. Not the wisest decision this woman's ever made as I'd had a few drinks but she didn't seem to mind. However he did not seem to like it, so I passed him back pretty sharpish. Maybe I'm not ready.

So time to go, Mark had called me an uber but when I went to get it, there was nobody there, and taxistas were being unreasonable with their prices. (Â£6) So I proceeded to walk for a little bit till I found a Portugeezer to do it cheaper. I'd recently topped up my phone but still had no data, so I could not call the uber and at this point I'd had enough of my phone so I bit it.

Yes. Bit it.

It then turned some funky colours before dying. It being dead was also annoying so I continued to vent my anger by linging it away. This is also a part of me.

HAHAHAHA as if there is a gif for it. Its not only me!

I then heard loud music and followed it to the modern art museum and spent some time trying to barter my way in or get some friends to sneak me in. This failed, so I left to find a cab, but with it being a lot of walking on Saturday I decided to have a wee lay down in what seemed to be a large scale nativity. I did not find Jesus, only lots of kings. I was then asked to move on by a security guard and found a cab nearby who transported me home for Â£4. Sorted.

So on Sunday it was me who was broken but I was not particularly bothered by my phone. In honesty it was gunna happen and it happens so often, I know all the avenues to go down. I probably shouldn't have got rid of it with the sim card but hey ho, I did. I was considering asking for a phone with a camera for Christmas whilst in the botanical gardens. So it makes my decision easier. Just don't bite this one.

Since then though all's been good, I hit up a Portuguese school to discuss visa options and it looks like a good avenue to go down, a proper school, proper visa and cheap prices for lessons which will help me reach the next level.

The language is going pretty well though, I'm hearing more, speaking more and spent the remainder of the Monday reading my Portuguese book in a nearby cafe, where the sun shone down and I enjoyed not having any contact to the outside word, really appreciating being here and everything that's happening. It was great to get those thoughts out of my head and since then I've felt a lot calmer and happier.

Even being able to write them down here and in my diary is a big help and a step. I encourage anyone who has similar thoughts to just write them down. It feels like letting the pressure of a tyre, through the pen and you can find yourself writing things that you didn't even know you had in you, letting your subconscious speak.

And I know I'm not alone because there are a million and one songs about this very feeling, which always helps to know others feel it, but I've always liked this song and it was always gunna feature. Seems like the right time.

item.title: Have Yourself A Merry Little Christmas
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
Ola,

Feliz Natal

Merry Christmas.

I feel like the Grinch atop of Whoville looking down (via instagram) on those below, enjoying all their festivities and their xmas boozing, driving home for Christmas and fireplace snoozing.

I say this because here, there is no Christmas excitement, a few things in the window and a few polar bears on TV. But there's no atmosphere around it, and with the heat pushing the 40's it doesn't really feel like Christmas at all. I think I've listened to about 4 Christmas songs, not including the annoying jingle bells jazz on repeat in the supermarket.

Here, I'm hearing from many people that the families tend to get together on Christmas eve and although they will spend Christmas day together, its more low-key. it's more about the day before, families celebrating the turn of Christmas at midnight and some exchanging gifts then instead.

I have no idea how Santa gets them here, or why he comes here first from the north pole, maybe he pops over after Australia but still, shouldn't he fly with the time zone? There's a few other holes in their Santa story that probably need answering first, such as why he wears a coat down here? Stresses me out. It's far too hot, I have the fan on full blast and I am still sweating my baubles off. Before I crossed the road to get to the sun, I now cross to hide in the shade. It's only the first weekend of summer and I'm genuinely a little scared of what's to come.

Though with the weather heating up there is a building excitement towards summer which means Carnaval, but before that everyone is talking about and looking forward to New Years Eve, where they will all wear white and in Rio, they will gather on Copacabana beach for what I hear is the best fireworks I'll ever see. Big praise, I've seen Andrew explode a plant pot at face level, whilst we all poked our heads over a wall.

So there's plenty to look forward to and while it may not feel very Christmassy and I'm not counting on there being snow, that's okay, I can skip it for one year, I'm already promising myself that I'll be home for next year. For this year I caught wind of a hostel who feeds the homeless so I thought that might be a good thing to do.

I was right, it was great fun and very interesting, they all seemed to appreciate it. I must be honest, I wasn't the most helpful in terms of actually feeding them. There seemed to be many gringo hands, which is a great thing, so I began chatting with the homeless people. One man, Romeo, began telling me his story, in fluent English. Why he chose his sleeping spot and his views on the world. He has a sister in America, who he is beefing with, and another who died of a drug overdose even after he went Liam Neeson to get her back from some bad men. He tells me how he lost everything and people were trying to contain him, how he's into sex, drugs and rock and roll and doesn't feel free in the enslavement of society, although he did agree he doesn't feel free in his current situation either.

It developed into a fantastic conversation on the education system and was really interesting to speak with him and a few others, of whom I could only speak a bit more basically with. There were two Americans giving them hair-cuts and a group of the homeless who played instruments while others sang along, all in Santa hats. The food looked good and I had not had lunch but I couldn't really, could I? I didn't. I already felt a bit guilty sharing a few beers with a local barman, particularly as one or two asked for some and I wasn't really sure whether I could. But they appreciated the food, many coming up to us to thank us and tell us how tasty it was. Although I wasn't sure if they were describing the food or the 'waitresses'. Some definitely were.

There were a few sketchy moments, a few began to argue with each other, shouting across tables and had to be calmed down. Also when a transperson came into the bar and a few began heckling her and the gay guy she was with. She obviously did not appreciate this and it became more heated when the barman I had drank with began to give the gay guy shit aswell. Their friend tarred me with the same brush as him and looked at me with a face like thunder even after I told him I agreed with him. But thankfully the barmen left as did a few of the louder homeless people and it calmed down a bit.

It was a great thing overall for most, they appreciated the company and it felt good, but to balance things out, I hope to be on the golf course one day this week, taking inspiration from my Uncle Gino who chose to do this last year, although I can't quite understand how he played in the cold. I'm definitely a fair(or more)weather golfer. So from the homeless to the golf course, I'm swinging both ways on this one... well when in Rio.

Its been nice to have a few weeks to myself and relax, catch up on things, particularly as I have had no phone to distract me or grab my attention.

I've spent days in coffee shops and bars reading or at times just sitting, and am finding myself being able to read for longer or let my mind wander off on ideas or solutions without it cycling back round to me and my mind. Mostly.

I definitely felt better for not having a phone for a while and honestly would like to go without one, but for all the downside it is a necessity and I have a new one, well old one, so my new number is +55 (21) 97246-4759. Holla at ya boy.

As I said, it's been nice, for all the good that comes with this lifestyle, it can feel very busy and unsettled at times. From the first month travelling, to settling into a new job and two apartments, sorting a second visa, learning a new language/culture and meeting lots of new people, it can be quite a lot of things to do.

I'm definitely feeling more settled but time flies by very quickly and before you know it, they want to kick you out of the country again and the visa procedure has many niggly bits to it, so it's important to start early. So from now and throughout most of January, time will be spent sorting the next visa, becoming a student and studying Portuguese so I can stay here just a little bit longer, for at least Carnaval.

First looking at all the procedure, was quite overwhelming and the amount of effort required seemed like a lot and would seem to take up the majority of my time, and also not that cheap considering I want to stay for like 1 month. It seemed long and I could not be arsed, already turning my thoughts about which country to head to next.

But when Jose called me out for being lazy. I laughed as I realised it was exactly what this is and I have began making movements.

Truth being, the visa feels like a cloud over me. Not a particularly dark or large cloud but a cloud nonetheless, it's the uncertainty of it all. I had a few weeks where I could live without having to think to the future or to the next thing as well as having no obligations. But for now, its back to making sure I can stay here, I'm taking the steps, and having already completed most of them, that I can do for now anyway, the cloud seems to be fading and what was once overwhelming is becoming increasingly easy. one step at a time.

Now although I call it a cloud, and it feels like that, it got me thinking about how lucky I am. The toughest part of my life is going through bureaucracy, but if that fails me, my next move will be where to live next? Argentina, Chile, Peru or Colombia, all of which will make me richer by default. Or go home to England, after the cold. That's a pretty cushty deal and despite the stressors that will inevitably occur throughout this process, the back up options are great paths also.

There are people who will be going through the same bureaucracy and uncertainty in countries around the globe and the importance of their outcomes could break up families or even be a matter of life and death. There are people in America right now going through these procedures to be with their young daughters and sons. There are people seeking asylum from countries who, if denied, could be sent back to a war-zone. There are those who are gay who could face deportation to a country where they would be killed for being who they are and loving who they want.

This has put things in perspective. I may have a cloud blocking a clear blue sky, but the sun still shines, brightly. There are those with blankets of grey, those with thunderstorms and those who have never seen the sun.

This includes those who are currently European citizens living in Britain and Brits living in Europe who are under massive amounts of uncertainty at the moment, I believe, and they may be forced to leave behind lives they have created. I haven't caught a lot of whats going on back home with Brexit but from here it appears to be a shit show. I have a lefty and a righty feeding me strands of information together and there seemed to be a lot of fuss over Jeremy Corbyn calling the sky blue or something?

But these things aside and to the now, I will be thinking of you all back home drinking together and getting cosy from the cold. It's been lovely to speak to people back home and hear of their respective Christmas plans. I synchronised watching Die Hard with Berty which was a Christmas itself and been in a lot of contact with my Mum and Dad who will be over to visit for a week in January!

In the meantime in between darting between government offices filling out forms, I'm finding great solace and peace of mind in coffee shops and bars as well as in even the smallest interactions with friends and locals alike. I hope you all have a lovely Christmas and a fun-filled new year.

Feliz Natal a todos e a todas uma boa noite!

item.title: Love and Hate
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
It's been 5 months so far.

In truth I've been thinking about this blog post quite a lot, the differences in culture, what's the same? What's different? What do I like about it? What do I not like about it?

I always have thought Brazil is cool, ever since the 1998 Nike advert where the Brazil team played in the airport with the song 'Mais Que Nada', one of my earliest memories. Since then all media has pointed to Brazil being a cool country. This relaxed place where people dance in the sun and on the beach. Amidst a few instances of crime.

But now I'm here and see the realities, do I feel the same? Is it as cool as I thought? What do I like? What don't I like?

For format I've gained inspiration from three places converging to form a trifecta of blog writing power

  1. 10 things I Like and Don't Like by sports writer Zach Lowe, a regular on the show the Jump.
  2. Love and Hate - by Michael Kiwanuka, an unreal song, hate is a very strong word for some of the things I don't like, but to fit with the song, Its gotta be, I get the feels from this song.
  3. 7 Things - by Miley Cyrus, not as good a song and I don't get the feels but fuck it. Miley, and a good number to stick to.

So there it is the inspiration to help spell the list inside my head. Enjoy

Love

1. Their snacks.

Guarana, Baconzitos and Ovomaltine

I can't even begin to explain the addictiveness of these three things

Guarana

A fizzy fruity drink that trumps any other before it. In fact the Brazilians are selfish for keeping it to themselves and missing a trick in the global sugar drinks market. Although fanta have their guarana drink so I'm sure they would dominate anyway. Actually I've began to overkill this and going off it. But still, the love's there.

Baconzitos.

Big salty, bacony crisps with a great texture. need I say more. Like frazzles bigger brother who everyone loves more than him and frazzles friends make whatsApp groups called 'baconzito's appreciation group' and always talk about how great he is...

anyway, they come in massive packs and if I open one it's usually gone before half-time. Even when I'm not hungry, they are so moorish and I can't stop (more Miley)

Ovomaltine

I know they have this elsewhere but here they embrace it in the right way. It's everywhere, in their supermarkets, their McFlurries, their Milkshakes. Malt is possibly the best flavour in the world. Strong in the best ales, including brewers breakfast, a lil' something which Harry's dad introduced me to in Cornwall, and here the Hersheys Ovomaltine is a staple for me during films. An absolute winner, I spoiled myself with a Christmas Panettone filled with ovomaltine which only lasted about 2 days.

They know how to snack and the streets are lined with sellers offering sugary snacks to passers by.

2. The weather

Ok, one of the kickers for here, was the weather, the sun does make a difference to how people feel and here its pretty much every day, every day's a beach day if you want it. Makes washing easier, a tan is great. Really brightens my day. Gives everything a glow. I also just love feeling warm.

I'm gunna sneak a 2b in here on a technicality that the weather and climate is who to thank for the nature around here. The city sprawls in and around the green mountains almost as if the mountains and forests around are part of it and embracing it. A hybrid civilization of nature and man-made buildings which when viewed from above is quite a spectacle.

3. The Soap Operas

I never thought I'd find myself so enthralled in a soap opera, let alone a Brazilian one. I hear they are particularly famous for their drama and the current one is actually amazing. What began as a tool to help my Portugues is now a nightly ritual. Every night, if I'm in, I'll cook in time to sit down and see whats going on in Serro Azul.

I'll be brief in my description but it's called O Setimo Guardiao (the Seventh Guardian) about a brotherhood of guardians who, terribly I may add, guard a fountain with healing-abilities within a small town without phones or internet. The characters of the town don't know about it, bar a few sneaky ones, but they all have their own dramas going on. The new (seventh) guardian's mother is on a mission to bottle the water and sell it for money and will stop at nothing to achieve this. There's also a man who was turned into a cat for having sex when he wasn't allowed to, because he was meant to be a guardian. Then as a cat he got ran over and died, but thanks to the fountain he's been brought back to life. All sorts of crazy shit going on. After watching for so long I have become engrossed in the intertwining storylines and feel so much love/hatred for the characters that I'm audibly reacting and putting up countless middle fingers. I watch it with my housemate usually but if I'm out in the barzinhos, it's often on the screen anyway.

Meet Leon (the cat) and Gabriel (the seventh guardian)

4. Style

I love the dress sense of the people, it's so relaxed. The streets are filled with people in flip flops, shorts and vests or casual t-shirts. The flip flops are a sign of a Carioca, as in Sao Paolo I'm told its not as common, but here, feet are liberated. I only ever wear shoes to play football.

The street vendors have a gallery of fake baggy sports shorts, and I see them everywhere, including in my wardrobe. If not sports shorts, its board shorts. Unless you head down to the beach and then it is particularly skimpy tight shorts that leave very little to the imagination. I very nearly treated myself to some snakeskin ones but have since decided otherwise. Luckily for everyone.

It's usually topped off with either a sports shirt, a open light shirt or a t-shirt with some, sometimes questionable, life advice. There are so many basketball shirts around, including a guy who spends his evenings and weekends in the barzinho round the corner and only ever dons jerseys of different teams. My hero. Unfortunately I have a Curry stained one that sits in house. To fit in though, I have now got a Flamengo shirt, the other staple as you walk the streets of Rio. The red and black stripes of their number 1 football team are everywhere.

If not a sports shirt, an open shirt which quite often will sport a funky design in light colours. Branches or birds are commonly found on these, as well as pineapples amongst other quirky things. I'm currently donning a white and beige one with blue and gold animal print. The coconut doesn't fall too far from the tree.

Which brings me to my only gripe with the style. The shirts are great but not easy to source, whereas the assortment of beautiful dresses or women's clothing is immense. I know it's 2019 now and I could wear a dress, but I don't feel or look great in them despite what the camera might say. The patterns are twice as exotic and 3 times as colourful. Maybe its the women underneath pulling them off but I don't think so. I must confess the leopardy shirt I have on is actually a woman's so who knows. Maybe 2020.

5. The language

I always have wanted to learn a language but I always thought it would be Italian and I do still wish to. But learning this language and speaking with people has been an absolute joy. I love the sound of it, I love the system of it and I love the phrases they use. With English having half a Latin base there are a lot of similarities which helps immensely with remembering and a lot of words require just a different ending, although that is a dangerous game to play. But once you get some of the system down, the guessing game becomes easier. I love to watch the TV, to listen to the music and to read it. I still have a long way to go but I am thoroughly enjoying every minute of the learning process and being able to communicate with the people is an great feeling. Even the smallest interactions.

Many times I straight up translate in my head, but sometimes there isn't a word that matches and in these occurrences it really is a feeling that I have that is translated. I can understand the word not through an English equivalent but a feeling inside and I love it when I can describe this feeling with one word.

Each language has a bunch of these that cannot be translated directly but convey a feeling and likewise we will have them in English, all very cultural things. I hear from friends that German is a language where they have a word for everything, its a shame it just sounds so harsh to me. Whereas the Latin languages just sound so beautiful. I very fittingly don't have a word to describe how communicating in their language makes me feel. Maybe I'll find one in Portuguese.

I guess actually the closest work I have is 'dank', a word only really popular in our hometown and friendship group, unless you head down to where Bainbridge or Harry have spent some time. It's definitely overused, but in certain times all you have to say is 'it's so dank' and people within the group will perfectly understand the feeling you mean, although it also has about 20 other meanings which can be a source of confusion to untrained ears.

I have a load of thoughts on this and am really loving the different perspective learning another language gives.

5. Dance

Any night you choose there will be an event on somewhere. Somewhere here people will gather at tables or just standing around listening to the music and dancing, but there is always a band playing music around. The music of Samba has grown on me immensely, in large due to the atmosphere of the events. With other genres such as Forro and Bossa Nova brings new sounds and moves and a new crowd of people nailing it. Sometimes I love to join in, other times I enjoy more to sit at a table and just watch them. And this is isn't even carnaval.

I really should have taken more dance lessons because they were great fun, possibly I will revisit them in the future.

6. The Bar Culture

This one is due to the many factors, some in this list. The drinking outside.

Drinking on the street, from bars or buying drinks from cheap vendors, of which many times you can take inside to events. People sit at tables spilling onto the pavements and many times pedestrians spilling onto the roads as well. Nobody appears to abuse it, I don't see many people getting too drunk or causing trouble and with people coming to collect cans for me the streets are generally tinnie free around the bars.

They don't seem to have a word for a roady though, which is a shame. 'A road beer' for those confused. And 'a beer to take with you while you walk to your next destination' for those still confused.

The service in bars I cannot fault, they bring you beers in a cooler and you share a large beer between company. When you are ready for another, simply place the bottle outside the cooler and a barman will come and replace it, after checking. A perfect system.

It works, largely because of the year round weather. One of the great things I love back home is the beer garden, which is a similar vibe, so drinking outside in constant heat all year round here is a dream.

7. the People

When I first came I guess I already had this pre-judgement ready that they would be very relaxed in many things but showing immense passion and overall much happier. I built a lot of this idea on the Italian or other Latin cultures I've interacted with. Overall though it can be easy to stick to this but as with anywhere there is just a great mix and many different types of people.

On the outside though it appears in general when on the metro or on around areas with a lot of people, they are comfortable, probably because in these situations they are all on the beaches or heading to the beaches, in the bars or usually dancing, having a good time. In the day on the metro it doesn't appear quite as glum as London does but its not vibezin either. I don't work with them so don't see them in the offices but one thing is for sure, outside of work they do have a lot of fun. The beaches, the samba and the bars facilitated by the weather allowing for many activities to continue outside. They hide from the rain when it happens so it's a good job it's not a common occurrence.

Maybe it's this balance of fun and work that they have right, who really knows, they definitely seem a bit more relaxed; walk slower, have no rush and I discussed the workers taking long breaks for football.

This is mainly in Rio though. I hear the Paulistas are workhorses and more serious, as Sao Paolo is more of a business city and has a different climate, many people comparing it more to London or other European cities. Doesn't seem my kind of scene and I've sided with the loose living Cariocas in their rivalries with the Paulistas.

Though it may appear this way, the more I've got to know people, there are those who get nervous, even though you might not expect. There are those who don't know what the word nervous means. There are those who are incredibly relaxed but also get very stressed at certain things and there are those who think to much and find it makes them sad. Those I can discuss deep topics with and those that don't care. They are just the same as everywhere when you get to know them individually.

Just here on the surface they appear to enjoy themselves. More sun = more fun.

Interlude

Now those are the things I love but of course, you cannot have the good without the bad. Yin without the Yang.

So here is a list of things that I don't enjoy as much, find annoying or just don't get it. As I said before hate is a strong word (for some of these) but for the good of the song and contrast, its necessary. So here we go.

Hate

1. Mosquitos

These little fuckers definitely warrant the hate. I like to think of the words of the Dalai Lama or eastern philosophies to not hurt living creatures, be compassionate to all living things. With most creatures (I encounter, at least) I like to live and let live, but these guys... They want a war, they don't want to just let me live. Not only are they known to carry diseases, they make you itch like a bitch. They want my blood and I don't want to itch just so they can live and continue to steal my blood. At times when I'm feeling particularly hot or annoyed or I've just had enough it's a full on battle as I chase them around the house with my strongest pair of flip flops. They are a bit slower than flies so they are at least killable, my room stained with the blood they stole from me before being splattered, without remorse.

At times I sleep with a top on to avoid too much skin showing to them but with the heat at the moment it's a lose lose. Which brings me to my next point.

2. the Heat

The yang to the yin of the weather, whilst the sun may brighten the world, its too close to Rio and at times can become unbearable. Thankfully it hasn't been quite as bad as I feared. My fan is on full blast and I'm just about all right.

At night though there's no relenting, no cool evenings at the moment and I find myself waking up sweating or with visual patches of sweat on the sheets. I also cheaped out on the suncream and bought some that I now think is made for bronzing, (many times I can buy things I don't really understand what I'm buying) and that makes me feel hotter, but hey, gotta wear sunscreen, as Baz Luhrmann says. If I like his life advice in the song, then I should really trust him on the sunscreen part too.

3. the Cashiers

Meu Deus, here is a downside of the relaxed nature of the Cariocas. They are too relaxed when it comes to service. Not so much in restaurants and bars as stated above, but in supermarkets, post offices, shops and banks. There is always a queue, and the shop assistants give no fucks. There is no sense of urgency I guess is the right way to say it and waiting behind one person can feel like waiting behind 5. When I first arrived, a friend warned me it will drive me nuts. I thought it was great to begin with, whats the rush. But after a bit longer, it's more whats the wait! I find myself walking straight out of shops if the queues are too long and have a beef with the speed of the postal office workers. Explains why my parcel was almost a month late. And this week I had a lady just chilling on whatsApp mid sale whilst I waited for her to finish her messaging before she continued to give me my change. I'm not the most patient but here is another level.

My friend Chris is a German students who works with Brazilian and his description of trying to get group work done had me howling. It appears a common notice of gringos here. Or anyone outside of Rio.

4. Their Food. Farofa. 

I've moaned about the food before, excluding the barbecues, it's just rather uninspiring. I don't go to fancy places often but apart from the Stroganoff they do here or the chicken hearts, not much excites me when I look at the menu. But it's alright, I guess. it's just not the same as when you go to Italy or even Vietnam, where there, the dishes are more satisfying and saliva inspiring.

And farofa, what the hell. With every meal comes a fried type of flour that I never eat. As a fellow gringo said...

"the normal gringo reaction to farofa is, 'why have they put sawdust on my food' "

that is essentially what it is. Some dry ass shit.

I'm not in love with tapiocas, a kind of a flour again fried with a filling in the middle either sweet or savoury, almost like a thick sticky tortilla wrap, with less taste.

But at least the snacks are dece.

5. The Roads

Always breaking. Always. Mini sink holes or cracks in the roads, Telephone poles falling in them, no road lines or order. Unless it's a serious mess, like last week in which the road near me just cracked and water was spilling everywhere, this will be left for a while with little change.

Thankfully I don't drive but when I ride the buses, the drivers have no concerns for these bumps and its more of a rollercoaster ride than a leisurely lift. The roads are all one way and no roundabouts leading to long waits at traffic lights of which again late at night, red lights are optional. This isn't too much of a problem for me, merely a comment. Like America though, the one way system and multiple number of red lights makes me nostalgic for roundabouts.

The pavements are also pretty shit and breaking, I've stubbed my toe many a time on the loose bricks and there are many wobbly drains that seem to always be so. There are wires hanging everywhere. I get tempted at times like a cat to play with a dangling wire before I remind myself it may not be the best idea.

6. the Word 'Puxe'

Its means pull but sounds like 'pusha', still getting used to it and have had many push attempts at pull doors. Always in the bank with the glass doors.

7. their President

The things he says about those more vulnerable, the things he believes about people being gay and that his moment of weakness brought him a girl. He's validated many people in their homophobic or racist thoughts and he's a danger to the Amazon. There's many a thing I've said before but he's just not a nice man.

He's came in to thwart the corruption of previous politicians and has made some, I'm told, questionable choices for the people around him. His son who has been elected as a senator is currently in the middle of a corruption scandal, and delaying the investigation, pushing it back as daddy backs him up as an honest guy. We will see. It's still early days.

Conclusion

So there's my thoughts on the place. The things I like, the things I dislike, Overall I think you can see that the positives outweigh the negatives, or many of the negatives are just parts of the positives that come with it. Or just small things.

I really am enjoying this place and still feel that Brazil is as cool as I had always thought. But now there are add on's that have enhanced it. I dig the relaxed nature that surrounds the place until the music begin when the atmosphere lifts. It's a good way of life.

A common theme I've noticed is the feeling I get from all the things I love. They make me feel warm, they make me feel comfortable, they make me feel dank. I have a weird image in my head sometimes of when I feel this, its difficult to explain, it's not even really in my head. It's an warm, orangey brown tinted feeling, almost as if a drop into a peaceful lake of orange that is spreading out along an x axis inside me. It feels consistent, like it will maintain, in contrast to the pleasure feeling of certain things of which I don't really feel colours or at times, feel all of the colours.

When feeling low it turns from this peaceful low lying orangey colour with a blur/glow into a harsh grey almost playdo that is twisted up in the middle of me along the y axis. A lot of my nightmares when I  was younger I cannot explain but everything was grey, lots of rocks were out of place, a lighter grey smoke was around. It just felt horrible.

I really would love to animate it, I know it may sound mental but its a feeling. The feeling of warmness. It's 'dank' and something I've been feeling a lot recently and that I'm mellowing out.

I've been having some great Saturdays sat at Parque Lage reading and having a coffee before moving onto beer, feeling just incredibly warm, in part to the sun, in part to the situation and of course in part to the beer.

It's a feeling that can be found in a song, a good book, a conversation, a kiss, a cuddle, a win, a cheers, a deep 3 point splash, a smile, anywhere.

It's comfort, contentment, mellow, jammin',

Dank.

item.title: Here Comes The Sun
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
Feliz Ano Novo Caras

I hope you are all having a great start to 2019

So far, for me, it has been, very happy and positive, thanks for asking.

It all started on December 31st, I'd been invited, through a mutual friend to a party in a swanky apartment overlooking Copacabana beach, the scene of the greatest new years party in the world or so they claim.

As we got ready, we drank a few beers whilst Jose was switching several shirts to decide which is his favourite white one. Luckily I had no such problem as I only have 1 that is both smart and white. Well it was.

We met the others across the hall and left to head to Copacabana amidst a sea of white, all excited with booze in hand. I should explain that for new years they all wear white and it's such a great idea, what a sight it is. As we got closer and closer the streets became more dense with party-goers and louder with volume before we reached the beach where people had begun to gather. I was very happy that our party was a good half a mile to the right, so we could wander along the seafront, taking it all in.

I've not really enjoyed many new years I will confess but I was becoming excited for this one. As we arrived, the party was in full swing and many people were already gathering on the balcony. The guy who had previously lived in my apartment before I, was a Frenchman who is now living in an absolute bachelor pad. Spacious, modern and minimalist with white walls and black furniture/tops (I think). Filled with beautiful people from all over the world dressed in smart white shirts and light dresses.

It was very cool.

I got speaking to a few even cooler people; a Canadian acrobat, who travels the world but still misses that time at home and the Latin America marketing manager for Apple who lives in a similar apartment in Mexico City. The best person I met though was one of the barmen who was hired for the event because he had such a fun loving attitude, it was incredibly infectious, he's dressed below in black, because as I later found out, he's evil. As midnight was drawing nearer he brought us some tequila shots that would be the beginning of the end.

But not at the time. With a few minutes to go to 2019, I found the group I arrived with and celebrated the new year with them on our own lil' side balcony. Onlookers from balconies, boats and the beach all cheered and hugged as the fireworks began to rise and light up the sky. I'm also not such a big firework guy but these were amazing, fireworks within fireworks, contrasting colours, red hearts and yellow stars amidst circles of explosions, all occurring for a good 30 minutes or more. Sorry Andrew, but you've been knocked off the top spot.

Shortly after they had ended, so did my bottle of wine, so I headed to my guy, who I at least thought was my guy, to get me a cuba libre, but instead got me something much meaner (stronger). The fact that one of my last clear memories was how strong the drink was is description enough. I'd been poisoned. After that it gets a bit blurry but I have a few memories of just trying to contain myself and calm myself down. I'm told I had a wee 10 minute nap and I remember being sat in a very plush chair chilling myself out. I'm also told we left at 3 but I can't see how we spent that much time there.

Oh well, it's New Years Eve.

We finished the new year by heading to the beach to enjoy the rest of the night. I spent the first while on a mission to eat chicken hearts, no I'm not kidding, they are dank (damn good), although that mission failed. I settled for a hot dog and began to feel a bit better. Physically. For some reason and for the love of me I can't figure out, I was feeling pretty angry and as I went for a dip in the sea, I thrashed around like a shark who'd lost his prey, maybe I was really peeved about the chicken hearts. Or maybe cause I'd got too drunk at the fancy party. I don't know, but I actually don't care, which is nice. As I walked back, I buttoned up my shirt and to let a bit more anger out, I pulled it apart and destroyed all the buttons. I've done this a few times, once after I got off the bus 1 stop too far. If I don't succeed then I button up the survivors and do it again.

This will be why you always see me in open shirts. Just kidding, I just really like the look, luckily.

I awoke the next morning, fairly fresh and without any worries, despite the drunkenness and anger of the night before and this has carried on throughout the year. I've been just being and enjoying myself. I've spent a lot of it reading my new book in coffee shops. I've began reading 'as melhores 100 historias da mitologia' or the 100 best stories of mythology and its been amazing.

I love the short chapters, I love the intertwining stories and I love the humanistic feelings of the gods. Tales which involve the darker emotions as well as the lighter ones. I had brief lapses of focus of which my mind would go to imaginative stories or plans of exploring Rome and Greece in the future.

Amidst that, and more administrative jobs I decided to use some Christmas money to enjoy a round of golf whilst I am here, so I went to the Olympic golf course to satisfy my need.

I had been exchanging messages claiming I had forgotten my handicap certificate and asking about shoes but they are so low on business it seems they said it was no problem and my basketball shoes would suffice, which is a shame actually because my flip flops would match my shorts and polo shirt perfectly.

It wasn't ridiculously expensive considering, even to rent clubs, until I got there and discovered they did not have lake balls I could buy and I had to buy balls at 3 for Â£10. Knowing my average of lost balls per hole, this could be a massive problem. I departed with a brave 6 for 18 and headed out into the 30 degrees heat with 3 bottles of water alone. When I say alone, I mean alone, there was 1 other group I saw all day and they were on the 9th as I was on the 1st.

To say I was rusty was an understatement, having no tee certainly didn't help as I began with a pea roller followed by another, straight into the small bushes. Luckily the  roughage was fairly dry and scarce. However I did not find that ball. I did find the ball I pwned into the bush on the next shot though and even found another. Finishing with a strong short game and a 2-putt salvaged a score of 10. Still a successful hole though as I left with the same amount of balls I began with.

It took a few more holes and a makeshift tee to shake off the rust, including one failed and one successful trip over a lake, before I got myself a par. I ended up with a few pars, 2 on par 3s, which I must say were very kind, and one par 4. My irons game was strong, a part that usually fails me and in reverse, my drive was wayward, a part which normally saves me.

The beaches here are incredible and the sand so soft, so I thought I'd spend a lot of time in the bunkers too. The next hole including 4 shots out of 2 bunkers , including a bunker to bunker and a cloud of sand evolving into a cloud of rage. Although as they were not my clubs, there was no hitting the floor, no linging and no putter volleys. Instead just clouding the head and forgetting the sand wedge as I begrudgingly raked the bunker and trudged off to the next tee.

I finished the front 9 strong and came out with a 54 but was running low on balls. with a quick break to replenish fluids and balls, now costing the same as the round, I was back out for the back 9. My first shot flew into the lake, and looked like a sign of things to come, but actually finished that hole well in what we call a doobs par (par without the wayward shot/drop). As I cleaned up a capybara popped out of the bushes to say hello and trundled off covered in mud to wash himself in the lake. He clearly did not see the sign saying there were alligators living there. Unfortunately I did not see any of those but the capybara was very cool, huauge.

Neither did I see any snakes that were supposedly around, the next hole was spent largely in the rough, and at Â£3.33 a ball there was no way I was letting them fuckers scare me, the alligators can keep the balls, but not them. It's a shame I didn't have my camera as I did also see some beautiful birds and the cutest owls who had nested in a bunker. They came and poked their heads out watching disapprovingly as I shot the ball out of their lawn, but they had the last laugh as I missed an easy putt.

I began to tire and make silly mistakes and get a bit in my own head but in what was a beautiful moment as I stepped up to the next tee, driver in hand, I audibly yet playfully told myself to shut-up mid swing as I powered through and hit the sweetest drive I may have ever hit. I fucking pinged it, probably a good 300 yards and in that my head went silent and I was incredibly peaceful. Even better the groundskeeper turned up with my sand wedge, and when I asked if he'd seen my drive he said he had. He must get the impression I am a pro. But at that moment I felt what John Mayer describes below and it carried through all the way into the 19th where I enjoyed a beer before heading home.

So this year overall has been incredibly peaceful and clear and I hope this will continue the whole year. I've found wisdom in the strangest places and am beginning to be. I've made most of the steps in the visa process and will think about my next step in February, enjoying the next month as pre-carnaval starts today, with a street party around the lagoon and my parents will be visiting in 3 weeks. Skies are becoming blue, the sun is heating up and I'm starting to come back, perfectly in time for the start of proceedings as the atmosphere warms up to the crescendo that will be carnaval.

I hope you are all having great years as well and this year brings everything you want, and if not, something better.

item.title: The Girl From Ipanema
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
Hello folks, last week my wonderful parents came out to visit and we had an absolutely cracking time, but to tell you about it I'm gunna pass the mic to my Mum and you can hear it from her point of view.

Enjoy....

The power of love and a hug ð¤

For those of you who are following Marcoâs blog you may be surprised to see that he has given his mum a guest blog I suspect as a one off !

If you are expecting me to tell you tales of falling asleep in a manger then you may as well stop reading now as you will be disappointed. ð

However if you want a heartwarming tale of how Tonino and I flew 11 hours on a plane just to give Marco a hug and see how he lives his life then please read on or pass it on to your parents to read and they will understand.

Firstly if we believed all the advice we were given about Rio de Janeiro before we went we would have never have gone, but the power of the hug awaiting us from Marco was too strong to ignore and in truth I wanted to experience the vibe of Rio for myself.

It did not disappoint as after a very big hug from Marco we set off on an adventure in Rio.

What we werenât prepared for was the hottest January temperatures in 90 years and it was indeed hot, 34c! It felt like walking into an oven but that didnât stop us as over the week we saw all the tourist attractions including; Christ the Redeemer, Sugar Loaf Mountain, Santa Teresa, Lapa Steps, Maracana (if any of my friends are reading this it is a football stadiumð) Parque Lage, ate in the restaurant that the Girl from Ipanema was written in and of course Copacabana and Ipanema beach ð.

Christ the Redeemer bought a tear to my eye as I had seen this iconic statue in pictures but seeing it for real made me realise I really had made it to Rio. The views were stunning and I wasnât prepared for the fact that you could see the statue almost everywhere you went in Rio and it was spectacular when it was lit up at night.

My imagination ran wild at Sugar Loaf Mountain as I pretended to be in the James Bond film Moonraker as we went in the cable cars where they filmed the iconic scene with Jaws ð.

We had the honour to meet Jose, Marcoâs landlord, who took us out to see parts of Rio that only locals would know about and made us the most amazing chocolate dessert to celebrate Marcoâs birthday before we went home!

Everyone we met in Rio was very friendly and we felt completely safe which is not something that can be said for some of the other cities we have visited.

What was lovely to experience was how well Marco has settled in Rio and he spoke very good Portuguese which was fab as we couldnât speak any. He was even greeted by a kiss by 2 of the waitresses in a cafe we visited so he clearly is mixing with the natives ð.

We also tried to act like the locals and I drank coconut ð¥¥ water and tried the local cocktail Caipirinha ð¸ on several occasions while Tonino sampled the table beers with Marco to help the local economy (thatâs our excuse anyway!).

Singing in the rainï¸ â

Marco and I are not known for our common sense so when we set off for a drink at Ipanema beach and we heard thunder we paid no attention thinking it would pass - how wrong were we. The rain was torrential and we were stuck under an umbrella in the beach for over an hour without a drink! Eventually we made a run for it but that was a bad mistake as it started again and by the time we got back to the hotel we were soaked - Marco tells me it hardly ever rains in Rio!

Sensible people I am told would have heard the thunder and thought letâs go to a bar nearer as we might get wet!

Before I finish my first guest blog, because I can, I am going to give you my Top 5 moments of my visit to Rio

  1. Seeing how Marco lives and meeting his friends
  2. Paddling in the sea in Copacabana beach
  3. Seeing Tonino and Marcoâs faces during the Maracana tour
  4. Christ the Redeemer - I really am in Rio
  5. The delicious meat I ate in Rio it really was delicious but I stopped at trying the chicken hearts!

Well thatâs me finished, we are home now and I can honestly say I will never forget my visit to Rio and if you are reading this and thinking about going just go - it really is fabulous darling ð ðð just like my son and that hug ð¤

item.title: Marco
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini

item.title: Just Around the Riverbend
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
Last Tuesday my second tourist visa ran out

The Friday before, 2 days after my parents left, I headed to the airport to rectify this. I had accumulated all the documents I would need, to study here for a possible six months albeit due to monetary reasons, more likely less.

Many people had advised me that Brazilian bureaucracy is a nightmare or that it depends on my confidence, or worse, who I will get, at what time and what mood they are in. Throughout the process however I had had 0 complaints, the first visa was a sinch and on the Thursday I went to get my last form that I'd almost left out for my second visa and the lady in the office went out of her way to help me, to get it printed in time.

So sure that I had everything, I washed and donned my best outfit, matching navy blue and light blue right down to my flip flops, and danced down to the airport with my files all organized in order in sleeves in the folder. I slapped it down with the aura of a man who was already accepted and then proceeded to take it out of the sleeves as they did not want it in that format but more of a pile.

After an hour or more of waiting, the lady came out but from the look on her face I knew something was wrong. One of my forms, the last one, didn't have my Mum's middle name on. Her middle name... Here they do attribute more importance to middle names but still, that's some bullshit. After going back and forth between another government office, they approved me for 30 days in order to get this form changed.

After a bit more back and forth, a lot more back and forth in truth actually I'm still not sorted and will have to go back next week again to try and get it done.

Many people throughout this process have gone out of their way to help me, speaking slowly to make sure that I understood and they have all been very warm and human. All apart from the bouncers at the metaphorical door to the country, that won't let me in.

In the meantime though I have still been enjoying myself, have begun more Portugues classes and attended my first bloco or street party at the weekend.

I had caught wind of a bloco starting Sunday lunchtime, near to my house, so I wandered over to the location, 2 hours after the supposed start time, of which there was no bloco occurring. Only a group of men dressed in an assortments of outfits, one of which I recognized from a previous stay at a hostel. This guy Alonso works in said hostel and is the epitome of party, he always seem to be where people are drinking and I don't think I've ever seen him without a drink in his hand or with his eyes fully open, but boy is he a good time. He features below dressed as Rocky. My Uncle has a theory that the party begins when the first glass is broken and I can confirm this happened at around 2pm, not 10 minutes after I had arrived and I'm sure it was either Alonso or his friend in a wig and bikini.

After another half hour or so we head east and stumbled upon the bloco nestled in a kids play area, of which there were also many adolescents drinking. There were other ages present, but in truth, to begin with at least, it did seem particularly young.

Fitting really that my first carnaval experience was parallel to my first partying experiences in England. Drinking cheap beers and vodka in a park surrounded by 15 year olds.

As the crowd grew and became older, I took myself away from the group to explore around and have a nose at what else was going on, the atmosphere was really bubbling. People in small groups drinking and becoming looser and looser with every passing minute. I took my camera with the original plan to take some pictures and head home to drop everything off before returning. That didn't happen. Always one more beer. In the future I won't be taking my camera. Probably. But I'm glad I did and people were more than happy to pose for me.

The band was there the whole time, just letting time pass, not rushing (obviously) letting the atmosphere build until it rose to a good level. I was on that level after a good few street beers and found a couple of English girls with whom I chatted until the band begun. The band was filled with many people with a variety of drums and bells on sticks. The bellers shaking their stuff whilst the drummers were absolutely going off as they began to advance up the hill towards the favela. The conductors of the group really setting the rhythm and the energy.

It was really quite something, wandering up behind a samba band, with sun beams lighting up the colourful houses of the favela and lifting the spirits of the people. As well as people lifting up spirits.

Shout out to the beer sellers hauling carts up the steep hill to keep the vibe going. You da real MVP.

I ran into a couple of friends from football, one of which had his parents with them. Sorry I couldn't get you to one Mum, but his parents seemed to be having a great time and really getting into the spirit. I know you would have been the same.

Jose also found me thanks to my location sharing but at the time I was amazed how quickly he got to me, and also how quickly he left, although I think that the booze sped time up a bit, or maybe I was just having such a good time. In truth I can't really remember the music, but I do remember the atmosphere of it all, it just felt lifted, a real noticeable level above normal, it had the feel of a fully flowing house party.

When we got to the end and they entered the venue, I stayed for about 5 minutes before I decided to head home. The pre-drinks is always better than the night out, I'd done a few samba nights before and I was feeling a bit drunk already, so I made my way down, took it all in for just a bit longer before finally stumbling off to my bed.

Day drinking is one of my favourite pastimes and the whole day was a really positive start to the carnaval season for me. I can tell this is gunna be a fun month. Albeit a heavy one. I have decided to start drinking water in between beers to maintain myself but that's sober me talking, the remembering-self talking. Not the experiencing-self. We'll have to see.

Unfortunately that night I then slept from 8pm till about 10:30pm and awoke to enter my birthday with a hangover, which is a new one for me. I was unable to sleep for the rest of the night but things were vastly improved by watching my beloved Warriors distinguish the Miami Heat before watching Moana restore the coraÃ§Ã£o of Tafiti.

The rest of my birthday was a relaxed affair but I really enjoyed it, just doing things that I wanted and a few beers. Thank you all for your messages, I appreciated them all. The rest of the is set to be a big month for me, with carnaval beginning, job hunting and big decisions to make. I have so many ideas swirling in my head but they are all positive. I'm almost brimming with ideas and cannot do them all, each day the next country changes, within 24 hours I had told Harry Argentina, Chile and Peru and in truth I still don't know. The matter of fact is that it is all depending on external factors and I'm ready to go whichever way the river takes me.

One of the teachings of the Tao is to be like water, in simple form 'to go with the flow'. I've always liked this branch of philosophy, the idea of just going with what happens but in truth the contradiction is thinking about this way of life and forcing yourself to implement it is in fact against the way of thinking, rather it needs to be within yourself to just accept the natural path that happens, the state of being.

I've probably tried too hard in truth and as a dear friend said, I get upset when it doesn't flow the way I want. In truth it's all going down a good path anyway so maybe it's due to this or maybe it's a change in me but I've definitely found more acceptance in myself and also the feelings I have. Allowing myself to be annoyed, lazy, sad, frustrated and dislike things has actually led to me feeling much happier and mellower overall rather than trying to stop it and letting it all out at once. It feels that rather than fighting things or swimming upstream that I have built a boat to be able to flow down the river and I am happy to go down whichever path it sends me and see what's just around the riverbend.

My mum and I have always loved this song from Pocahontas and she likes to play it when taking me on an adventure, she also likes to shout 'NOOO' when it says 'should I marry Kocoum?'. I remember when I was at uni, late at night if I was sad, drunk or just fancied a walk I would head to the sea and just look out for ages, way before Moana made it cool. I don't know why, I didn't have any plans, or any idea I would come this far but at the time it was pretty liberating.

Anyway the next step is unclear but I am moving forward and at the moment I'm not striving for an end goal but just enjoying the path, and am enjoying the idea of not knowing what this next year or what life has in store but I must say it feels pretty perfect right now.

Physically right now as I sit here with my basketball on the TV, Google playing some jammin' music, all being controlled by my phone. The connectivity is insane. I have a different drinks mat for each drink and baconzitos are on sale.

The weather has cooled down this week and the fan is on half speed. It's one of those moments when all senses are satisfied but now it seems to be maintaining longer.

I remember in an inebriated state one night in uni when I returned home and felt particularly good, the lights and music were a good level and it felt like 5 orbs aligned and joined in perfect harmony and it's beginning to feel like that again.

item.title: Electricity
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
I had the best Monday I have ever had this week.

It really started late Sunday night into early Monday morning, the soap opera that is the NBA delivered an entertaining crossover event with all of the best characters involved in the All- star game. Although never a great game, all the little storylines make it an interesting watch, particularly the battle between the splash brothers, Steph and Klay. I love a bromance.

So I went to bed in a good mood and awoke to 3 fantastic lessons at work and a contract extension, with hopefully more stable opportunities.

Then the guy that I buy lunch off every day had my favourite dish, chicken Stroganoff and I was so happy, I bought 2. It's always a good day when he has Stroganoff. I just didn't know how good it would become.

I returned to work on one of my websites which turned a corner last week and led to an increase of output and learning before heading to my Portuguese group class for even more learning.

But the real reason came late in the evening. A German guy, Silvio, who had appeared in one of my classes last week, had invited me to join him at an 'Ensaio' or training for carnaval. There are many of these around and you can go and watch them prepare themselves for blocos or the parade in the famous Sambadrome. Through his Brazilian girlfriend's family he had caught wind of a deal for residents to join the parade for cheap and I was absolutely down to join.

I headed across town via metro to the center, where I met him. Now Silvio is about 12ft 9. For the first time in my life I found myself having to walk quicker just to keep with his ridiculously large strides. He looked more like my bodyguard than anything else. We asked a few people around for the samba school and again everyone was very willing to help and going out of their way to help us.

Following their directions and hearing the music close by, we found the drink carts outside and decided to have a Caipirinha whilst waiting for our contact to read the message that we are here. I think that first Caipi really added to the tone. After moving onto a beer and no reply from our guy, we entered the large hall where a samba band was playing and saw that a few people had started to line up at the front. About 5 abreast and in small blocks, which I am informed are called alas, people began to assemble. Some groups a collection of different people in different attires and other groups all coordinated in both outfits and dance moves. Highlights were a group of gentlemen tipping their hats many a time, a group of older ladies in long skirts swinging around and a group of younger ladies who will invade my dreams for years to come. They were stunning.

As the band began, the song they played was an absolute banger. This song played on repeat relentlessly for 2 hours and it did not get boring. In fact it stayed in my head as I walked back from the metro station. Two moments in particular really gave me a great feeling, similar to a drop in songs, or like a nice note. Two kinda contrasting songs that I can relate the feeling to is in 'Electricity' by Dua Lipa atm, I cannot deny, I love it when she "cannot deNYYY" the feeling she has and 'Over the Rainbow' when Eva Cassidy really nails the "finndddd meeeEEEEeeeEEEEE"

These moments came about twice every 5 minutes as the groups began dancing round the room in a oval shape, and following each other singing at the top of their lungs. I had acquired a song sheet that I shared with a lovely Amazonian bloke who loves carnaval in Rio. I stood there, a Caipi and a few beers deep with the infectious atmosphere really dragging me in. And this was only a training.

I took a quick break outside to replenish beer and energy and film a lil' clip for my nanny when I saw three lovely older ladies having a good old chinwag. They had matching outfits and stood by the samba schools symbol, the lion, so I asked them for a picture. Again they were more than happy to take one and invited me in. It was great, when I told the one without the hat that my friend and I were keen to join she dragged me along to find someone who could help. That guy took our number and said we should come on Friday to register in time to get a costume, attend a training and be ready for carnaval.

You don't need to dance well, you don't need to know the words, just need to amble along with some energy and rhythm and you're good to go. There seemed to be about 4 moves that were 'fairly' synchronised throughout the whole squad, the rest depended on the ala, of which most had a high energy guy at the front leading the group. And after about an hour of walking around the room singing and dancing, people began to have the words and the moves down.

The atmosphere was honestly ridiculous and I was so filled with excitement, we chatted the whole way back and I sang and danced into my house before then sitting down, writing and taking inspiration from the events that had occurred, I listened to one song on repeat that had a good flow that could have a similar effect and keep the energy going. I didn't want to go to bed and didn't for another two hours. I contemplated cracking open the red wine but decided against it, thankfully.

The morning of writing this is the Tuesday and I am still on an absolute buzz, although I must say my vision seems to have zoomed in a bit. I know it sounds mental, and it is, but its a thing I know others have experienced and I used to as a child. Everything seems a lot closer than it is. A lot. Peoples faces, this computer, that empty beer can. Internet diagnosis says it's either too much electrical activity in the brain or that I'm dying. In truth I think I need a clean and a nap to calm myself down but what a feeling. what an atmosphere. What a night.

It's now Friday and this week I also acquired my visa to stay with the potential to be here until August. However unfortunately the deal is too late to join up and it is now too expensive to get the costume, so I will spend the money on another costume less extravagant but more ridiculous and dance in street parties instead. I'm honestly gutted about it but that's the way it goes. Monday was still incredible and gave me a great experience and I can't wait to see the actual parade in action.

I was gunna drop in the song I was singing but as I wont be singing it, I'll drop this in instead.
