item.title: Samba de Janeiro
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
So here it was, Carnaval, the week I'd been waiting for, the biggest party in the world. The thing everybody has been talking about since I arrived here.

It began on Friday the 1st of March and ran through to March 6th, Ash Wednesday. This being their version of pancake Tuesday. A week long celebration before shutting off for lent.

I think celebration is actually a bit too weak of a word to describe it.

In truth as the dates got closer I had other things preoccupying my mind and as Friday rolled around I wasn't fully in the Carnaval spirit to say the least but I was willing to join in and fake it till I make it. It's funny that I went through all this effort at the visa office just for seeing this week, essentially, and then I just wasn't feeling it. Everybody was telling me I can't miss this, particularly not as I had stayed here for so long and was planning to leave mere weeks before.

Boy, were they right. This was a spectacle to see and it is the best time in my life to see it. As a single adult after living here for 6 months and being able to speak the language it all seemed to come together so perfectly.

It began on the Friday night but in truth, it is not the biggest night as many people still work until 5 and there is a whole week of festivities to enjoy. This year it was not helped by the absolute downthrow from the heavens which would later entrap us in a house high up on the hills of Santa Teresa.

We arrived late to one of the first blocos, which is the name for all the street parties that occur during the Carnaval season. Some move, some appear to be more like shows. Each type has a theme, although a lot seem to share a common one of a walking band containing a lot of drums and brass instruments that play samba as nearly naked humans flaunt around drinking beer and taking whatever else they can to get them in their vibe.

We missed on our first attempt and as we went to the house of a friend to sort out our previous argument we ended up passing the time drinking inside and being silly until the rain passed and until I, along with my roommate, could head home. The evening could be best described using the phrase 'failure to launch'.

So we made sure that on Saturday we would hit a bloco and actually begin, although not after a morning of watching the football and a few table beers from the bar round the corner. As 3 o'clock rolled around and results came in, the girls came over, we donned our skirts and began to get up in the mood.

Still not feeling overly confident at this point, I donned my easiest costume to wear and began with the first of my Disney princesses, Snow White. The costume may have been a bit small and the skirt, barely covering my y-fronts, did not leave much to the imagination but boy did I have legs to die for. Still not feeling confident, a quick flash to social media gave me a barrage of complements and not so complementary statements, but indeed more ones of fear or disgust.

My friend questioned whether it was ok to go out in, not being sure whether it was legit or too revealing. However in a lovely bit of serendipity, the first person we saw after leaving the house was a man in a skirt more see through than mine with just pants and no shirt on. If anything I was a prude.

But away I went with my nunnery self to the bloco where the first guys we encountered immediately stepped to the girls with a Brazilian style confidence I will never understand, actually too much because the girls swiftly moved on as we battled our way through the crowds following the music. It was definitely too busy but a fairly enjoyable experience. The street was abuzz with excitement and debauchery, all in the disguise of men dressed as women or an assortment of characters. My particular favourite is this girl who went as one of the toy story toys crossing a road. 

Maybe not.

But then after battling through, we parted with the float that was pumping music through and decided to make our way to another bloco, but not before that Brazilian confidence was shown again but this time in the form of a woman who stopped me dead in the street and looking me directly in the eyes, exchanged very few words before going in for the kiss. I had heard about these sort of things happening here but didn't really believe them. Thank you legs.

We were on our way out though and headed in search of a second bloco. The metro on the way was insane, people chanting and banging on the sides, everyone getting involved.

The Carnaval spans all over the city, for miles and during the peak there was about 5 different street parties going on at any one time in just one region. It really was incredible and as my friend said, its not just a type of people who attend or a concentration. It's everybody in the city. Young and old, Black and White, Cariocas and Tourists, all dressed up, all half cut or more and having a good time. Although actually whilst we were on the metro I was not and after another argument, we went our different ways and after I couldn't encounter the 90's bloco, which I am assured was amazing, I made my way home, still in time for the soap.

I think I've made it clear in previous posts they don't work particularly hard, per se, or to be fairer to them, they are just not get up and go kinda people but fuck me, during Carnaval they are, the parties begin at 6, either carrying on from the night before or people arising early to party.

Jose who I hadn't seen surface before 9 on any given day, was out in the morning at 8 to head to blocos, feeling lazy cause he missed the 6 o'clock one!

I was not so early and it took a little longer before we finally went to join him. Feeling a little better in myself, probably after being kissed, I donned my Ariel costume, which I think I absolutely pulled off and we made our way to meet Jose and the girls, a couple, both named Clara. After a metro ride of people chanting and dancing again and a few location mishaps we chased them and found them at the front of the bloco, moving at a pace. The name was Boi Tolo and it was by far the best one we went to.

The main cursor for a good bloco is space. If the road is a good size and you can move freely its 20x better than being squished and moved along, with one arm stuck in the air and one in your pockets. The Clara's were respectively donning a sea-esque outfit, which matched well with me, and a football referee, with ball, whistle and cards to go along with it. And a moustache, which she worked into all of her outfits. I loved it and at many times, as the bloco was moving, we found a bit of space and began games of keepy uppys with passers by who joined in and gave jeers when someone would fuck it up.

We followed this bloco for miles but the beautiful thing was, it was taking us home. Another good cursor is it being close to home. When you come out and you are close to home its a marvellous feeling. With it being spacious, good weather and temperature and good fun it really made it perfect, we could duck in and out of the epicentre of the party when we wanted/needed and saw many people in great costumes as we passed by. As we were nearing home, legs were tiring and the sun was beginning to mix with the beers making us all a little tired. We kept on for a little more to head into the tunnel before reaching Copacabana and in that tunnel it went fucking off.

The acoustics and atmosphere were incredible and the band built it perfectly, slowing it down, getting everybody crouched down in anticipation before the drop. The whole tunnel becoming filled with sweaty, drunk, happy party-goers jumping around chanting to the sounds of samba. As moments go, it was up there and will always be what I remember when I'm old sat in my chair, telling my grandchild about how when I was boy we didn't just virtual reality to places. We all went back and indulged in steak and beer to finish off before getting home at a good time, ready to begin again the next day. They love to party in the day and relax at night and I gotta tell ya its a good idea, we all love a bit of day drinking. But they do constantly have the sun.

This time I decided, upon recommendation, that I should get up to go to a morning bloco and chose the Sgt Pimenta (pepper) bloco to sing along to a few songs where I knew the words, not just sounds. But in truth when I woke up my body was not very happy with me. Thankfully I had committed already and with a friend pushing me for time, I knew I had to get up. We arrived 35 minutes after the previously agreed time but 5 minutes after the secondary agreement and we were pretty proud of ourselves for this.

This time it was more of a show and upon first arrival, this time in my more low key outfit of Minnie Mouse, I was struggling to get up for it, whilst my friends were already on some strong sweet wine thing which is honestly a terrible thing. Would not recommend. But in all of sudden, probably correlating with sips of beer, the energy came back and it flowed through us throughout the whole morning as the band gave samba renditions of Beatles classics, some not working but others improving on the original. Highlights including the whole crowd belting out 'I wanna hold your handddd', the obvious banger - Twist and Shout, the lovely and meaningful Blackbird and an impromptu scrum with some Brazilian rugby lads nearby. I'm so glad I got dragged out and being pretty drunk dancing along to Beatles samba classics at 11 o'clock on Monday morning was quite something.

We returned in a mischievous state but packed in a wedge of carbs before the next bloco. The less said about that the better. Thankfully though it was close to home and when I snuck out it was amazing to just be able to walk 10 minutes to return and relax for the next day of festivities.

These festivities however, took a considerable amount of time to bring ourselves round to. After 4 days of partying it was an effort to pick ourselves up again, in fact even the Brazilians were showing signs of weakness and in an mutual agreement we committed to one later in the afternoon to give us time for a bit of R & R. But I still had my favourite costume to don - Moana - and we technically had two more days. It started slowly as we wandered through the piss-stenched centre in search of blocos and as we reached our first one, it was far too busy and offered no comfort whatsoever. In truth it probably helped us prolong the drinking and made for a longer lasting enjoyment as the second bloco became great fun again.

Staying still for a while before parading through the centre we lost ourselves numerous times, thankfully I had my oar, which I was very proud of and Carla had weights for her strongman outfit, and a moustache. Plus a back up moustache. As the road shrank and enlarged, the feeling of the bloco really ebbed and flowed and after a short following through the center of town we made our way to a bloco much closer to home, oh so sweet home. Here the vibe was more dancey and funky but again it was absolutely going off in the streets. We got chatting to a couple of American girls and after a few expensive table beers to finish the night, we went our seperate ways.

If you're now getting tired of this, good, you're beginning to get an idea of how I was feeling and for most, the Carnaval was over. Ash Wednesday was here and it was time to begin lent and the fasting in old times of food and in modern times, alcohol. But oh no, not for me, In the evening I had some friends visiting from England and they are not particularly known for their relaxing demeanor or for having a few quiet ones. Thankfully they didn't arrive till late on the first night to allow me to recover.

As they arrived, we were immediately on the beers in the hotel room and I was pushing through but as an opportunity arose to meet the girl I kissed on the first day, I left them as they went to meet their other friend who was in Rio. It was a very relaxed atmosphere as I joined her friends in the bar. They were all leaving early the next day after a week of Carnaval, which was a shame but we still had a great time, we spent the whole night talking and laughing and looking into each others eyes like we were the only two people in the bar. I really felt an amazing connection with her for such a short time, only for her to leave the next day. But that's how it goes sometimes.

The next day was a down day for Carnaval and I too took the advice, only having some pool beers in the day where I got a good chance to really catch up and have some chats with the lads from home. It's been nice to see some familiar faces and touches from home and it's also been great to show them around, particularly when I took two of them into the infamous Lapa. In an airbnb near to the famous steps we made our way down to indulge in the party atmosphere, and after Bainbridge was on his second Caipirinha in a matter of minutes, myself an Doug only being two sips into our first one, I'll never forget his face watching the 'mean' man pour a truly obscene amount of cachacha (dirt alcohol) into the drink. Bainbridge had already commented to me half way through about how much was going in, the more he poured, the bigger Bainz's eyes went and the more surprised his tone. Here he is.

As we sat having a table beer I could see Bainbridge was well on the way and after they couldn't believe how mental the road was, it was time to head into a club. The funk club filled only with Brazilians was our first destination and as we began dancing with some girls, myself slut-dropping, one of the girls asking Doug to dance, to which he replied, 'I am dancing' and more than he ever has before. We hit up another bar with just as mean drinks before making our way back at 6 in the morning to finish with a night cap on the balcony, overlooking Sugar Loaf mountain and the streets of Rio.

We're almost there. One more night. If I can get up for it, you can read on.

Another slow starter, thank god as we slept in for a good while before exploring the neighbourhood of Santa Teresa and taking part in a few table beers with both, friends here and at home, which was a lovely affair and a good laugh before returning to go to the Sambadromo at night. Fuck sake. I haven't even began to explain the Carnaval parades. YouTube them, the cars are amazing, the costumes extravagant and the people happy. One guy fucking surfed the air on a bunch of drones.

Anyway, we went to the parade of champions and sat watching each samba school go past. On TV they all looked incredible but in truth, we went cheap with the tickets and were sat too far away to appreciate the detail and atmosphere. A couple of caipis deep we decided to rectify this and Doug hatched a plan to infiltrate the VIP area, so down we went, deciding to go with the Englishman, not fully understanding approach and I'm not a terrible blagger of things but Doug appeared a different class, I think at one point I even believed he had lost his tag and deserved to be in there. After trying a few entrances we retired to find the others, before seeing an opportunity to go in the back way disguising ourselves as parade members. Many costumes had been left in piles outside waiting to be discarded, so we picked up a few larger hula style skirts to try and blag our way into the participants area. The guy on the first entrance was having none of it but we soon found a way around that and made it into the first section, the decompression chamber if you will and just as we swaggering into the final sector we were thwarted by another who came to stop us. Can't fault their security on the parade. Boy this place functions around Carnaval.

So upon returning to Lapa, we ditched the skirts and finally reaching my limit, I grew tired and left the boys to enjoy themselves in the mean streets of Lapa. Of which I'm sure they did until the early hours of the morning.

At the moment, they are having a bit of a relax in the supposedly blissful Iguazu Falls while I fall back into normal life.

It's been an amazing 10 days or so and I've had a wonderful time and it was definitely worth it to stay and see. It was truly marvellous, but now I'm very ready to relax and get myself back in my routine.

What a week.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: <iframe width="300" height="380" allowtransparency="true" frameborder="0" allow="encrypted-media" title="Spotify Embed: Samba De Janeiro - Radio Edit" src="https://open.spotify.com/embed/track/2OFNudaD0TiwN4PAjLudtm?si=voqbtYUaTv66P7mp5bOQIQ"></iframe>

item.title: A Real Hero
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
So I've given her a makeover.

Before the layout did it's job but I've spent the last few weeks creating something to give her a new look. Mainly just for practice and creating something to which I can now upload posts and other content to without having to code them in. Which has good implications if any y'all want a website. Any feedback is welcomed, things you like, things you don't or any suggestions. It's all good. Screenshots from different devices would be handy.

Thank you to Mike for the help, the families pre-live screenshots and to the real MVP Nana for checking its functionality and signing off on it.

I've had to go through all the posts which has been both nostalgic and long. I particularly liked the ones at the beginning, more frequent and lil' snippets, so I'll try get back to that.

It's definitely calmed down a bit here now. Saturday nights have been spent in. My drinking has been a lot less and I am more than caught up on the soap (Shit is going down in Serro Azul, I tell ya that). It's been lovely. The whole town seems to have calmed down including the weather which is a blissful temperature. Still hot enough to go to the beach but not so hot that you have to jump from shade to shade to get there.

Everything since carnaval has seemed to be going beautifully. My Portugues is reaching new levels and overall I just feel more comfortable and confident. Unfortunately for y'all that contentness has been matched with not doing much out of just happiness doing nothing.

I always think back to my psychology lectures, about the rats who had a button to access to a dopamine button and they just continued to press it because it felt good and they did fuck all. They loved it so much they chose it over food and sex and had to be unhooked to save themselves. I'll try not to do that. Upon research I found a pretty sketchyarticle that builds on this in trying to correct a homosexual mans orientation. Wow, I forgot how many sketchy studies have occurred in the name of Psychology.

For me its less pleasure fixes at the moment and more serotonin and a more mellow feeling. I let myself feel the pleasure though on Friday with Beer, Dominos and Netflix but by the end of the evening I ended up feeling pretty shitty. After a very frustrating battle with my stream, only to watch the Warriors get robbed in ridiculous fashion, I went to bed livid. This continued onto the next day at the beach, where Sheffield Utd conceded two late goals to lose me Â£80 and I continued to drink and buy anything off the sellers which passed me by to alleviate this frustration.

I eventually left earlier than first intended after an agreement with Mark to a dry April and returned home to finish my beers in the fridge to remove any temptation and begin anew the next day.

After a long sleep and nothing to do on Sunday, the two days could not have been more contrasted and I was happy as Larry, listening to chill hip hop whilst I shaved, cleaned and danced (not at the same time) all after sipping on a coffee watching the imitation game, without the subtitles.

I love having nothing planned. It's so freeing. It doesn't necessarily mean I'll do anything but I can, at any moment, depending on how I feel. When I was asked to help my friend move apartments I was delighted to oblige and it became a great afternoon with him treating me to lunch out.

I have nothing really planned for April. I've really settled and will spend the next month not drinking, Working all afternoon and learning more web development while just being happy hanging out in the house. Just living.

All preparing for April 14th which marks the beginning of both the NBA playoffs and the final installment of Game of Thrones.

Life looks to be pretty good right now.

Many nights I find myself in low lighting with a basketball game on the TV, my google playing, munching on Baconzitos. Bliss. Tuesday night, the Warriors were already in playoff mode destroying the Denver Nuggets and I watched the whole thing whilst listening to a playlist based on the song below.

Everything was, and still is, perfect.

<iframe width="300" height="380" allowtransparency="true" frameborder="0" allow="encrypted-media" title="Spotify Embed: No Surprises (feat. Janelle MonÃ¡e)" src="https://open.spotify.com/embed/track/4cRPXadQRylHEWmQJ02fIc?si=uSGMz72lQ-KXuwxsKHO-Iw"></iframe>

item.title: Untitled Reusable Block
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini

item.title: G.O.O.D Friday
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
I've been watching a lot of peep show recently which is the perfect show, the inner monologues really nailing it on the relatability scale. It's very self-degrading and beautifully honest. I would recommend it to everyone. Everyone British anyway.

For me it really normalises the negative emotions and I find myself laughing hard at all their honest thoughts that they don't say. It really is a masterpiece. In a time like today it's great to have this considering everywhere you look, primarily the internet, is telling you how you should feel. Makes me feel a lot more human.

That's probably part of why were all so anxious, feeling terrible for having these feelings and thoughts, people telling us we're bad to think them or telling us how we should feel in a situation. Or even our own head telling us that how we should feel based on what we think others feel. I've been having many of my own negative thoughts and feelings this week.

In truth, I have isolated myself a bit here. I'm working online in the mornings, learning in the afternoon and content to chill at home in the evenings. Only leaving myself the weekends. But that was of course the point from the beginning. If I'm doing that at home, I may aswell do it in Rio and explore new places on the weekend.

Since Carnaval, I feel ready to move on but this situation is so good for learning, living and the NBA. I will stay for the next 2 months before I move; who knows where next. I'm definitely ready but there's alot of things rolling around in my own head, contradictory things and silly things that end up putting me in a bit of a loop.

I'm feeling a little repetitive => I should go away for the weekend => I don't have the money really => need to work => not doing that much => will go travelling over the summer => planes emissions & money => need a job and feel a little isolated => maybe I could get a job in an office => need to learn more => repeat

It all just rolls around, with a bit of self loathing thrown in there about my abilities, my self-centeredness, the fact my 'weak' brain is cycling in these thoughts and also because I'm feeling bad in a hammock in Rio and I truly shouldn't. But I did.

It's all good now though, was a few days in the week that just sent me west. It happened and it's gunna happen. It's not that there's anything wrong with me, I just didn't feel good for a few days. I've had such a good time recently that maybe it's just equilibrating. I'm sure that's a word.

In truth it may have come from a lack of sleep on the Monday due to basketball and even worse on the Tuesday after the Warriors loss. I'm not even joking the last two times I have felt low have been conveniently after losses.

Now that they are back on track, so am I, even with little sleep after watching them last night. Surely it all has to be a coincidence? Or maybe just an extra lil' boost. Surely I'm not that unstable, am I? It could even be cause I'm not drinking. It's probably a little bit of all of these things that all just came together at a point along with some untimely arguments.

But I was talking about it and did things one step at a time, and the Warriors won big, so life is good again. I've been writing this in a hammock by a pool before I took a electronic scooter, flying past others riding or walking along the beach front of Copacabana, all closed off to cars for the public holiday.

It's been a big swing but I can't really complain. Riding along the beachfront on a sunny day in Copacabana really lifted my spirits, along with the workers in the hostel (that I had previously stayed at and was writing in today) welcomed me in for lunch with them.

Its Good Friday and I'm heading to to kick a football around with some of the lads I play with here. It feels a lot like heading to the park in Summer, but it's on a beach in 28 degrees in mid-autumn. It also gives me a tick off the ol bucket list. Something inspired by David Beckham's documentary through the Amazon.

Play football on a Brazilian beach

Tomorrow I will go hunt for Toucans, with my camera. The merchandise of Rio has it everywhere, they have got to be around here somewhere.

A bit of social interaction, a ride along the beach, a kick around and a walk through nature. I feel good again.

Happy Easter.

item.title: In My Life
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
It was a week of hard fought battles which had me sitting on hand switching knife edges. An end to many a season as Winter is coming in the Southern Hemisphere.

The battle to sit upon the throne in League one was at its finale, the band of men in Luton trying to secure it from those nearest the Ports Mouth and those in the North. The Realm of Men in GoT defending their ground from the army of the dead in a battle for survival at Winterfell. Meanwhile in the Bay Area the native Warriors also defending their ground and their oracle, holding off the powerful James Harden and his men who are trying to avenge the last battle between the two teams. Meanwhile, Meanwhile! the Avengers were trying to amend their previous battle with a similar powerful tyrant who also seems to be unstoppable. Inevitable.

These 4 wars, each having more than 1 battle, were all starting to settle, but to watch it all unfurl was definitely less settling. I was not even on the edge of my seat but completely out of my seat watching as the tides turned, some points seemingly done for before brave heroics and big moments giving hope. The heroes, the golden boys, the orange, the life, conquering the evil, the dead, the beard and the mean supporters.

Throughout those 4 days I was very highly strung and feeling all the emotions. screaming at the TV in both joy and anger, non stop moving around the house, with a blanket draped over my head feeling intense butterflies. As each closely fought battle drew to a close, I was hit with huge senses of relief and with surges of happiness flooding my nervous system, at certain points overflowing out of my eyes.

Watching the Avengers at the cinema, the whole room was feeling it. It was so emotionally charged. People loudly sobbing everywhere, people shouting and screaming at different points.

Bloody Latins and their emotions.

I cried at 4 different points and actually shouted at one point. I couldn't hold back, I didn't want to. It was the perfect ending to all 22 films.

As Wednesday May 1st came around it provided a much needed break from sports and media and a well deserved drink (I had a dry April). Despite the nerves, I loved it all; the feelings, the little outbursts of emotion and thankfully all results going the right way for me.

They all battled and fought which has been in (tony) stark contrast to in my head this week, which is a nice change. A lot of the time there's a battle of voices in my head, sometimes taking the form of other peoples. But at the moment it's only mine and it's rarely arguing.

Now I'm not saying that its all external factors but of course they are a nice little push. Everything is going perfectly and I'm really doing a lot more of things I want. I've been reading, walking, buying fruit, learning and everything feels very clear, warm.

As the seasons all around are coming to a close, so am I, ready to move on. I have big plans to tour around a bit more of South America and things seem to be coming together nicely. As soon as the playoffs finish and that's all concluded I'll be looking for my next location as I begin to move again.

With the talk of leaving and moving on I've been asked a few questions by those who I spend my time with. Whether we'll keep in contact or we'll stay good friends and both of those discussions have concluded that we will most likely still stay in touch but will evidently drift apart. That's life and it is almost inevitable but it doesn't mean that we won't still be friends. We all agreed we will always send little texts or reminders to each other when something sparks the memory.

I love it.

I've been to a lot of places for fairly long periods of times and made good friends there. All the time I receive little messages or send little messages, not in a way to just keep in touch or to be nice but because of the spontaneous recalling of a fond memory. Whether it's running around Sweden doing Alan Shearer's, bumper cars in San Jose or getting stuck in a cove and being rescued by the lifeguards. These things are constantly brought up as we look back and laugh.

In between my little learning sessions at home, I have my chromecast showing my facebook albums that briefly take me back to a particular moment in one of my trips. It's in this moment I might drop in the message just to reminisce. Sometimes the message is no more than a wave and a basketball emoji sent (Lloyd). Sometimes more, yet other times I will just sit and smile as I think about that moment or that person. I will do this even as I sit in a retirement home many years from now, as I know my nan still does and if I can be even just this in another person's head then I'm happy with that, even if I never know or we don't speak. Essentially in the end that is all we will become. Memories. Living on in the minds of others.

But with all these little look backs it's important to also look forward and continue moving on. It's great to see people on instagram from old places or old friends in new places, or even new friends in old places but sometimes it can take you out of your timeline looking back or looking elsewhere. Sometimes I delete the app because I find myself doing just this but I'm always redownloading it the next day cause in the end I enjoy seeing other peoples lives. It's just important to stay in mine, not looking back wishing I was here, there or elsewhere. Which I'm doing much better at.

At one point I'll find that place where I want to stay and continue making memories but it's not here. It's too far away from back home but it's still been an amazing experience. When I see pictures or things occurring in Brazil in the future I will always look back here with fond memories as I do to Morzine, the Bay Area, Cornwall and Home.

item.title: If You Want To Sing Out, Sing Out
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
That's all folks.

For now.

The monkey's out of the bottle

I had been keeping the fact that I am coming home a secret to surprise my very sharp and difficult to surprise brother, whose birthday it is this month. The lengths we all went to not let anything slip was well, far. We paid attention to every little detail to ensure he could not even harbour the thought that I was coming back and we succeeded.

It was all worth it to see him at that moment and it has already been golden just to spend some quality time with the family. I am home for 5 weeks and although I will be involved in many family activities I hope that I will get a chance to see most everyone at least for a small part.

I remember the night before I left for Rio some 10 months ago, a friend had asked me what I wanted out of this trip? Good question. It always started as a jump forward as I found myself becoming stagnant at home. I had an unclear view of what the future held, even what I wanted it to. I stumbled with an answer along the lines of, 'what I want to do' which was in part true and from the way things have worked I have answered this, at least for the next 5 years or so, so problem solved.

In actuality the fact that I struggled to really have an answer and at times struggled to really express myself or say what I want to say, was what I was looking to free myself from. Nina gets it, as do the Lighthouse Family who did a fantastic version.

And I sure did. I allowed myself and my thoughts to run free, sometimes to darker areas but I have found myself speaking and thinking freer without my own judgement. I've allowed myself to feel things and emotions without telling myself I shouldn't, such as anger in certain situations. It doesn't mean I've acted on it but by actually by allowing myself to feel it, it's become more naturally easy to control it. If you think and act only on how you think you should how can you understand yourself at all. I've let my head run free and have found myself becoming more disciplined. By knowing what things lead me down a good path, both physically and emotionally, as well as what behaviours and thoughts send me down a bad path, I've been able to install habits and behaviours to control it, my own mental programming.

At times I would let myself wallow in my bed or just let my undisciplined thoughts take their hold but over time I realised that it is in these moments that I needed to begin to think positive or get up and do something. I needed to be kinder to myself. Do things I didn't want to in order so that future Marco doesn't have to. Over time this is getting easier and easier to do and it is becoming more habitual.

As I have not moved in the past 10 months or actually travelled, I realise that this travel blog has become more of a mental health blog, or a platform for me to speak my mind. At the start more exciting things were happening but after a while there's only so much I can talk about basketball, the soap, table beers and coding, which became my life. Thank you for reading it anyway. It has been important for me and I feel 10x clearer, more confident and stronger from it.

Travelling is not for everyone. Even sometimes I believe I am not the travelling type. There are those better suited to the continuous social demand and comfort zone escaping that takes it toll, but boy do I enjoy living in a new place and exploring it. Building friendships over time, finding hidden or not so hidden gems and understanding the place.

I would also not recommend it to everyone, it depends completely on their personality and situation, those who have a social group nearby in which they hold a sense of belonging or an other half who they love by their side. You are not missing out. You have your own journey which brings happiness. Both sides have green and mud patches.

However if you don't have those things, it's a fantastic opportunity in which you will see some awesome sights and experience completely different things and ways of living.

If you do have the urge, I would recommend going on your own at least for a period of time. It gives you the ability to be yourself in a place where there are no previous preconceptions of you. You can choose to do the things you really want to do, take the beaten path, be a trailblazer, see only the old pubs or just nature or just sit in a hammock and do fuck all. You can also choose where to go or where not to go, go to places with people you like, donât go to places with people you donât like. It is all in your hands.

I chose to stay and work online which allowed me to explore my craving of coding and realise that that is what I wanted to do. So I stayed in my cozy flat, working away and doing the little things with my few friends and flatmates.

That did isolate me a little bit and with fluent English speaking flatmates I slacked on my Portugues. If  I was doing this again and I almost certainly will elsewhere I would work somewhere with a workforce where there is forced contact with people and gives time to build relationships. I would also live with non-speaking flatmates because it would give that necessity to learning the language and would speed up the process.

That being said for this particular time, what this was, was perfect for me. I needed some time away to think about a lot of things and discover whats real to me. Over my last weekend in Rio, I have been the strongest Iâve ever felt and incredibly happy and it is in part thanks to the city, the culture, the people I've met and the fact I've done things my way.

I am back for a month to see familiar faces and embrace and spend time with those of whom Iâve been missing. Upon return I will visit a new place in Brazil for a few weeks whilst I wait for my friend Harry to come out and escort me around South America. For those of you who know Harry Sinclair Waugh know that there will never be a dull moment. I will continue to move around and will begin to write again, this time about; the places, the culture and the experiences.

But for those of you have read along and encouraged me as I wrote I thank you, particularly Nana, my biggest fan and who I continued to write for. This whole experience has really allowed me to get out of my own head and really allowed myself to be me, who I am and who I want to be, not who I think I should be. For Mike, who asked me what I wanted from the trip, it was exactly that which I wanted to achieve.

item.title: Black & Gold
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
After a lovely month at home visiting family and friends, I've come back to Brazil, if only for a short time this time.

Whilst I was back I was telling most people I would be heading to Salvador because I was keenly interested in both the culture there and the history of the sugar plantations. However as money IS a thang, I opted for a shorter, less expensive bus ride to the small old mining town of Ouro Preto, translated to 'Black Gold' due to its gold's distinctive darker colour.

For anyone who saw me in the last few weeks of my UK visit, you may have heard me talking about the book 'Open veins of Latin America: The Pillage of a Continent' and it was indeed that. Of the many sites of the plundering from Western Europe and later on the USA, this town caught my eye. Not only was it in Brazil but it had links to British history.

In the late 17th century the Portuguese 'Bandeirantes', in charge of hunting runaway slaves, stumbled upon, well a gold mine I guess... in the town of Ouro Preto and began to extract it; as the town grew, slaves began to be imported to do the extraction. It actually had the most amount of gold mined, but in the shortest amount of time, leading to an incredible gold rush that saw a lot of profit for Portuguese merchants.

During the time it was being mined it's name was 'Vila Rica' or 'Rich Village' and had a higher population than that in New York or Sao Paolo. The town expanded rapidly; many churches were built and houses became more and more extravagant, regularly being passed by by large processions and a host of festivals.

Meanwhile back in Europe and thanks to some savvy work from the British, we brokered a treaty with Portugal which allowed them privileged access to trade their wines in our market with less taxes than France, who we were at war with at the time. In exchange for this and for military alliance, our textiles and manufactured goods were to be traded free of duty in both Portugal and it's colonies resulting in the shutdown of production across all their countries.

Now our cloths had a bigger market and allowed production to develop in Britain more so than the wine production did for the Portuguese. Our exports began to outweigh their exports and they fell into debt to us as they became dependent on our fine imports. For a while they paid with the gold from ol' Ouro Preto until it began to run dry.

As the gold dwindled so did the profits of the town's merchants and because the Portuguese crown took a hefty tax, these merchants became frustrated. Thus inspiring a failed independence movement from Joaquim Jose da Silva Xavier, lovingly known as Tiradentes or âtooth pullerâ due to his previous job being a dentist. Him and his posse each faced a brutal end, Tiradentes being drawn and quartered with his head then being remonstrated around Ouro Preto in order to deter future attempts. It is in the square named after him that I would enjoy my coffee, books and beer.

In a paragraph titled 'How Brazilian Gold helped progress in Britain it claims that the majority of Brazilian gold ended up in our hands helping us develop our industries and also gain control of the Portuguese Trade. This treaty gave us vast amounts of wealth and allowed us to flourish rapidly reportedly moving Europe's financial center from Amsterdam to London. So if this book is to go by, we owe a lot to this lil' town back in the UK. As we became wealthier the only remnants of the gold in Ouro Preto was inside of the many churches previously designed by the towns many artists. Quite a spectacle.

Nowadays it is a UNESCO World Heritage Site holding its colonial architecture, it's cobbled streets and it's impressive house fronts. If something is to be built here, it must keep with the theme.

So I was drawn to this place and as I explored each day, loving the cobbled streets but hating the steep hills, I found my own little golden spots in the cafes and the restaurants as well as the best routes which required the least climbing. I would work morning and night leaving me about 6 hours in the day to visit churches, squares and bars. I spent a lot of time doing nothing but reading in the Sun, which during the day counteracted the coldness of being at a higher altitude.

Despite the cold nights, there appeared to be a Winter Festival going on throughout Ouro Preto and the next town along. I couldn't believe my luck as my 2nd and 3rd favourite band were both playing it! The chance to see them both whilst I was there and on two different nights, either side of a weekend I was mostly working, seemed like the perfect opportunity.

But it started off terribly.

As I explored the neighbouring town awaiting my 3rd favourite band 'Melim', increasing amounts of young Brazilians descended, dressed in a similar fashion to that of the 'chav' that many of us dressed as in secondary school. I'm talking, caps, trackies, gold chain 'n' all. Although considering this was the gold capital of the world for a short time I kinda hope it holds some more heritage than our Argos links did.

Despite not being terrible themselves, Melim were largely disappointing. So I left early to get the last bus back. Now bad things happen in threes. The first being that I had missed the last bus home, due to the shitty app Moovit just being plain wrong. I had to pay my lengthy bar bill in cash so I had little left and upon entering the bank and pressing the ATM the alarm began sounding. Loudly. So I had the equivalent of Â£2 to get back to the next town, or have to pay on card for a hostel, which I was not keen on.

After the policeman had told me to just wait for a lift off of somebody, I did so for over an hour before a man with a minibus took a bunch of us back.

Beautiful. I was tired but back in the town, just down the steps to home.

Walking down the steps I moved to the side to make way for another and stepped in the gutter which had no steps, so as I stepped my foot slipped from underneath me and I fell, caining my elbow.

I trotted back tired and in pain, aching for my bed, when in the street next to my house I saw a pack of 3 dogs all combine and head towards me. Fuck sake, not tonight, leave me be.

I covered my arms with my jumper and tried to just walk past calmly, I leave you and you leave me kinda deal. the Alpha of the pack didn't agree to this deal and began jumping up at me, for what I now presume was the shitty vegetables in my back pack. Now he wasn't super aggressive and he didn't get me but I was having to parry his attempts away trying to keep him down. In a moment I saw my gap and I began to run. I sharply realised this was a bad idea, so I turned and began parrying again, telling him to calm down. Thankfully this time he did and the three dogs then escorted me back home to where I quickly unlocked the door and swiftly entered. Finally home.

As I got undressed, I thought I'd better check that there was no marks and as I saw a small hole on my jumper and a cut/burn on my elbow where I had fallen. I began to think that maybe he had nipped it. I was positive it was just the fall, but late at night, alone in the room, the mind can try to convince you otherwise.

To be sure I spent the next day going to the hospital where I was given the all clear, some reassurance and some cream/antibiotics to fix up my cut.

Over the rest of the weekend I began to relax about it more and more each day, but as it was again quite a solitary weekend working a lot, the niggle of doubt was still there despite professional advice and extremely slim chances.

As Sunday rolled around, I took the evening off and headed downstairs to drink with the students I'm staying with before heading to see my 2nd favourite band 'Lagum' who despite playing in a strange arena both thin and long, put on a great show and created a great atmosphere.

It seems Melim's show begun what was to be a weekend of work and worry which was then book-ended by Lagum's fantastic show to really bring me back to normal.

The rest of the week has been spent back to reading in coffee shops and exploring ever more as I wait for my bus-ride back to Rio where I will encounter one Harry Sinclair-Waugh and begin a month of frivolous enjoyment.

item.title: Hazil
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
Hey Y'all,

Excited to welcome my second guest blogger to the stage, the unpredictable, the lovable Mr Harry Sinclair-Waugh...

Hello to all my fellow Mazil followers. I'm very excited to be contributing to the blog that I've kept a keen eye on since its inception a year ago. The aim of the first weekend of our trip was for me to experience how what Marco's life out in Brazil was like, and by the end of it I'd come to the conclusion that he set up a pretty enviable life up for himself out here. The whole time I've been here I've just been overwhelmed with pride for how happy he made himself here.

We've laughed a lot at how until he was with me Marco never really got the full gringo experience of Rio. His Italian complexion has managed to disguise him as a native so it's only really been this weekend in my company where he's gotten to understand the concept of the 'gringo tax'. I've also really enjoyed just standing and smiling while he chats away. I don't feel like too much of an ignorant brit abroad for not understanding what's being said, my overwhelming feeling is one of pride. I see how Marco is valued here in Rio just as much as he is down the Malt Shovel in Bubbenhall. Whether its customs he's learnt through spending time getting to know the city and the people, or his natural appetite for mischief, scheming and cutting humour, the main thing this weekend has taught me is that Marco fits in in Rio. 

So in a way it was sad to be with him as he leaves, but also lovely to share his last weekend with him, celebrate his life in Brazil, and get giddy with excitement for the rest of our trip together. I'm also incredibly excited to return to Rio in 2 weeks time where I'll meet Hannah my girlfriend. I've already warned her that my 3 days in Rio will almost certainly mean I'm guiding her round and acting like I've lived here for years.

I arrived on Friday feeling rather strange. This may sound doom and gloom but I have really struggled with the guilt of flying here and these feelings were obviously at their most pronounced after being on a plane for 13 hours. It's something I have to deal with, I've made the decision to fly here and I'm almost certainly gonna have to fly back unless I decide to abandon my life back home which I actually happen to like quite a lot. My guilt achieves nothing for the planet though and the only way I'm making myself feel a bit better is by holding myself to an agreement never to fly again after this trip (I've already looked into how long it takes to get back to South America by boat as I'm certain that one 6 week trip is not going to be enough, answer: a nice leisurely 14 days. 

I maneuvered my way past a gang of mini cab drivers who spotted me for what I am: a suggestible, gullible Brit who's never traveled this far on his own, and found myself en route to Marco's friend Jose's house (where Marco also used to live). Seeing him for the first time was obviously fantastic and after quickly freshening up we were on the way back out to Lapa. I felt pretty brain dead and couldn't really contribute any meaningful conversation but luckily was able to follow as Marco and his friend Mark gave me some very basic Portuguese lessons and spoke about Carioca shenanigans that they've engaged in since living here. My ability to chat was enhanced by a few caipirinha's (the drink of choice on most street corners) and they took me to Lapa steps which is the setting of the video for Beautiful by Snoop Dogg and Pharell

This was when I really saw just how well versed Marco is in the Carioca (I can't get enough of this word as it makes me feel like I'm in the know) way of life. We danced to some Brasilian funk and laughed with increasing volume and persistence. Before we knew it it was 6 in the morning. Realising I'd been up for 28 hours was enough to put the night to an end and we both slept very well once we were back. 

On Saturday we walked to Ipanema beach, seeing Rio by daylight gave me a strong second wave of excitement and by the time we got to the beach I was fizzed up and ready to blow, especially when I got my first glimpse of dois irmaos, two of the magnificent mountains that loom over the city. I had a dip in the sea and wasn't met with the warm calming hug I was expecting but rather some pretty gnarly waves and a temperature not too dissimilar from what I'm used to in Brighton. It's the middle winter here and just from one weekend I can almost guarantee that I won't be coming back in the summer as it's hot enough for me at the moment. We then got a motorbike taxi up to the top of Vidigal, a favela with a fantastic view over the whole city, and enjoyed one cerveja before realising that we just about had enough cash for the journey back down. 

We arrived back at Jose's and then went for a night out in Botafogo. Marco informs me that due to it being the place to be for arty types and bohemians it's nicknamed Botasoho, after entering one very trendy Berlin-esque bar that had an irritating and seemingly pointless payment scheme I told him it would be much more apt to name it Botapeckham but he wasn't having it. Again my excitement was uncontrollable and I had bags of fun talking to Marco's friends and dancing (I think I'll need quite a few lessons before I can fit in on the dancing front). 

On Sunday morning we woke and got the bus to Parque Lage, a sprawling  park full of beautiful trees that seemed to just have just sprouted out of the middle of the city. I knew of it from speaking to him as the place Marco came to on a Saturday to celebrate or commiserate depending on the results of his Saturday afternoon bets. As we wondered up the hill Marco casually informed me that we might see monkeys. My response to this was far from casual and sure enough when I saw them I turned into an excitable child (my baseline for most of this trip to be fair) and couldn't control myself. There were so many of them and the way they moved between the trees was so graceful. I also saw a guinea pig that looked about 4 feet long but Marco missed it as it scuttled past his feet. He informs me that it was actually a capybara. This whole experience left me losing my mind about the prospect of going to the amazon later on in the trip. 

In the evening we played football with a group of friends that Marco met quite early on in his time here. This was also something that made my childlike excitement bubble over into uncontrollable levels. Part of my fascination with Brazil has always been its relationship with Football and just walking around Rio you can tell how football mad everyone is. After much deliberation I decided to adopt Flamengo as my Brazilian team. Botofogo seemed more apt as it was where Marco lived and where I'll be staying when I come back, but their one game I watched left me far from impressed. (Also Flamengo have far nicer shirts).

Playing football with Marco and his friends underneath one of Rio's many mountains was wonderful but quite early on I fell on my knee while attempting a Ronaldinio-esque step over and realised that if I injured myself badly I could really fuck myself up for the rest of the trip. From then on I stopped playing at full pelt and backed out of a few tackles. This wasn't met with sympathy from Marco's friends however and I found myself on the ground a couple more times. 

On Monday we both said goodbye to Rio, Marco's goodbye was obviously more significant than mine but I was also very emotional about how wonderful the our weekend in the city had been. Our journey to Buenos Aires included a brief one night stop in Sao Paolo of which I will pass back to Marco

It was very brief and almost never happened. With 20 minutes to go until our flight we decided to check where we were actually flying to as the board had been saying Campinas despite the check in lady confirming Sao Paolo. It was about 80km or an hour and a half drive or about 4 hours via public transport. We laughed, we boarded, we arrived and from there discussed whether to stay in Campinas, or continue on as we had to be back in the airport in 18 hours. 

After fairly careful deliberation and more due to the discovery of the free shuttle service we headed to our hostel where Harry would become a legend.

We were roped into playing cachaca pong with one of the hostesses and some Australian douchebag giving it the biggun, and for those of you who have seen Harry can probably guess he's no Steph Curry on the table. His juttery throw was the target of many banterous advances from our opponents and all in good fun Harry was providing the entertainment as we 3 traded shots.

As they hit their last shot we were given a shot at redemption, holding my nerve I sank it and kept us alive. After a few more attempts I hit the first of their 2 cups. This was his moment. One Shot. We'd called it from the start. Harry for the win. He begins his motion. He shakes with his motion. Releases the ball and it glides straight into the cup securing the win and proving all his haters wrong. Storybook stuff. 

I run out into the street screaming, I can't believe it. As I come back I find out our opponent is lifting him into the air, which I wasn't pleased about, he should be crying into his cachaca. After he bought H a celebratory Jager-bomb, we left for the nearby bars to celebrate with some food and drink before a good nights sleep and a flight to Buenos Aires.

Tchau Brazil. ja com saudades. (I miss you already).

item.title: Freaking Out The Neighbourhood
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
Tchau Brazil, Hola Argentina,

Now I had many preconceptions about Argentina; First there was our rivalry that we have always had, mostly in my mind built by football. Many games always bringing up the memory, which I have never owned but can see so vividly, of Maradona punching the ball.

There is also the playful rivalry that Brazil has heaped on top of it. Not really sure where or why it started but I and the Brazilians enjoyed hating on the Argentinians together. An enemy of my enemy is a friend.

Upon arrival to the country, I was quickly developing a 3rd reason. As we were hoping to get the Uber to our hostel, 3 consecutive drivers told us to cancel and pay cash, of which we had none. Apparently Uber is illegal out here and throughout the week it seemed to be the wild wild west with regards to Uber and their lawless drivers. We had decided with our Monzo card that the best option was to get cash out in the center of the city.

Argentina did not like that.

The Uber drivers would not take us, the taxi options were extortionate, and the bus company would also only take cash. It was set up to mug us off and as we decided to get cash out for the bus we saw the Â£10 fee to withdraw it. Fuckery. As we laughed and got out money to take the bus we encountered a Dutch traveller who did not see the funny side of all this. He had just come from Australia and could not wait to go home in 5 days.

Eventually we arrived, 6 hours later than originally intended and just decided to spend the first night getting some food and chilling out. Start again tomorrow. Although the food was basically pasta in milk.

We had recently discovered the request money option in our Monzo accounts and after lots of humorous transactions between Harry and I, I decided to open it up to the floor. Many cheeky requests were sent to friends on Monzo for a beer, the idea of a request popping up on their phone prematurely made us giggle but it was even more enjoyable as many people accepted the request, treating us to a few beers around Buenos Aires.

Shout out to Jossie, Harvey and Josh Chilman for the goods. Ameet declined the Â£100 request to get Harry out of jail. Some friend.

Everywhere we went seemed to be taking us for a ride and with little Spanish or knowhow to get us by, the gringo tax was hitting us hard. I tried on many occasions to just speak Portugues and despite Harry reminding me its not the same language, it worked a lot of the time. Although conveniently not for the gringo tax.

We met a Brazilian who lives in New York and two school teachers and spent the first real day wandering the backstreets in search of football tickets. The infamous Boca Juniors were playing in the Libertadores, the South American Champions League, against a team from Brazil. After a hefty walk and a heftier lunch bill we sourced the tickets out in a bar overlooking the canal, where we drank in anticipation nearby a group of Brazilian football fans. Buenos Aires Away Days.

As we wandered towards the stadium we were met by many riot police and a dedicated section behind metal sheets for the fans to enter, we were told many of the fans were police escorted in by bus but we had no colours or even really allegiances. It may have appeared that way however as we were swearing at the Maradona mural whilst surrounded by Argentinian police officers with mean looking batons. Not the wisest thing we've done. Not the stupidest though.

Once inside I began to swell with Brazilian national pride against the Argies. The joke now being that I am becoming a Bolsominion. Ha Ha. Ha. The real fans there had a real respect for Boca though; after falling behind to them 1-0 in the first leg, Boca have never failed to go through in this scenario. One fan told me if Athletico Paranaense won, he would give me his shirt. Which I don't think I would want as then the Boca fans would probably batter me. Another fan offered for Harry to stay with him in Brazil, on two separate occasions. Other fans were saying that they are here for the experience, to see the city and the Boca fans who did not disappoint.

Similar to the Maracana the drums were non stop accompanied by singing although rather differently here, many of the fans, in the center of the main stand, stand on metal bars that are not fit for standing, holding on to fabric that descends from the rafters. I couldn't believe it but apparently it's true. Towards the end of the half they began to become loud. Intimidatingly so, but we (loosely used) managed to get in 0-0 at the half but the hope of a smash and grab goal to force penalties was still alive.

Pretty early into the second half that hope was vanquished as Boca scored. The Brazilians were silenced and the Boca fans became so loud and were jumping around so much around that the stadium shook. Physically shook. It was mad. Concrete stands. Then as the second goal went in towards the end, us along with many fans around us began coughing as what we now believe was the dust had been shaken off the stands and into our throats.

A mean kick while we're down and an intimidating message to not come to Boca and try to win.

After a few more beers we also conceded the night, the next day moving across town to a neighbourhood recommended to us by a friend David Iwanandfheuinfjrhethczi (not his real name) who used to live here for 6 years. I've been pestering him for tips and boy did he come through with this neighbourhood. Possibly the coolest place I've seen. I loved Botafogo and still do but this place is ridiculously cool. It's filled with funky bars and coffee shops amidst a few trendy shops, all very up my street.

As I walked around there is a brisk feel to the air reminiscent of ski towns as the shops all house various scarves and ponchos which is something I am definitely sold on. Just trying to brave the cold until Bolivia where I hear they will be considerably cheaper and the weather will, worryingly, be considerably colder.

As I type this Harry is currently warming up to play in his second football match of which I have given him a series of tasks to complete in order to get a meal tonight. Just to be clear, it's to buy him a meal. Not withholding food here, although that would spice it up a bit. 100% pass success rate so far.

This comes off a great result for his beloved Leeds in a copuntry where their manager Bielsa has filled Harry with excitement to be able to discuss Leeds, Newell's old boys and El Loco, his nickname. He has been frequently seen wearing his In Bielsa we trust which the Argentinians have loved.

We also have found a few pockets of nature in Buenos Aires, visiting the cities ecological parks, experiencing some beautiful views and intriguing animals to go alongside some decent conversation. Harry has told me he has found himself being drawn to the nature side of travelling and preferring areas of peaceful greenery. Which is great as we are headed to the Amazon next week in Bolivia.

So all in all after a shaky start which did nothing but reinforce my thoughts on Argentinians and feelings on Brazilians, I've been won over and Palermo might be one of my favourite places in the world. It's been completely relaxing and enjoyable just doing what we feel. Half of the time filled with red wine which has been as fantastic as advertised and I myself paid a pretty penny for a steak which was well worth it's price tag.

We've met some great people here from all over and I experienced a dope moment chilling with two of the hostel staff. I spoke English and Portugues. The french girl spoke Spanish and English and the Brazilian spoke in Spanish and Portugues. So as we spoke we switched between the three languages, not translating, just having one of us not understand at each time as the conversation rotated.

The Brazilian guy also told me he wants to learn English so he can visit England because he loves the Specials which led to a long discussion with Harry aswell about Coventry and how he should definitely come visit it. Something I never thought I would recommend.

We have learnt bits of Spanish and I'm intrigued to learn more, whether I will stay and learn more or go back home or back to Brazil is still up for dispute but all of my choices are 10/10 choices and as I sat and wrote in my diary having a coffee in a corner in some cool neighbourhood in Buenos Aires with one of my best friends just around the corner I feel pretty blessed, even without Christ looking down on me.

item.title: Empire Ants
item.dc:creator: marcociuffini
item.content:encoded:
You last left myself and Harry in Buenos Aires or just leaving Buenos Aires on our way to Bolivia, via a quick pit stop in Santiago, Chile.

At the time of booking, the layover looked a dream, 10 hours and a quick chance to see Santiago and no need for a hostel. However Santiago was smoggy and spenny. We popped in briefly but we did not get to see much, just one neighbourhood and we weren't particularly impressed.

After a few sleepless hours in the airport for myself (Harry had found the best seat in the house) we made our way to La Paz. I hadn't really told Harry about the altitude so that came as a bit of a surprise for him and also for the person in front of us who fainted on arrival at customs. Feeling very out of breath and light headed we sat down and grabbed ourselves some coca tea and sweets to alleviate the feeling that one feels at 3600m above sea level.

After a long day of travelling and also trying to acclimatise we had ourselves a lengthy sleep in preparation for the next day of travelling and the real reason we came to Bolivia. To see the Amazon. We had heard of a small town bordering the Amazon named Rurrenabaque of which there were two ways to get there. We chose to take the 35 minute flight over the 18 hour bus ride on what was named 'the Death Road' deemed as the most dangerous road in the world. We have heard mixed reviews from those who took the bus but the flight was fantastic. The views of the Andes were incredible as we flew over with its white topped mountains, neighbouring vast jungle of which we about to delve into.

Upon landing the contrast in climate was extreme and we all of a sudden found ourselves in blistering heat having to be conscious of mosquitoes. But at least we could breathe normally. We grabbed a tuk tuk into the town, a grid system of dirt roads in which we had no place to stay, no tour booked or no real idea or expectations.

After a short water and wifi stop we decided on a hostel and had a few ideas of the tour. We spent the rest of the afternoon running around the town being indecisive about which tour to take. So many options but in the end we went with our gut and to what we were later told was on the more expensive end of the tours, but is so for a reason and rather good on the eco side of things.

Satisfied, we went for dinner with a Canadian anthropologist- to-be who had been all over Bolivia in a variety of ways and through some adventures having just returned from an Iowaska retreat. He took us to this lil' family run restaurant with possibly the best meal I've had in South America, (sorry quentinha man) and at the cheapest price. A moist rice base mixed with what I think was shredded beef topped off with a fried egg and some plantain. Right next to us in the street was a butchers where the head of cow was on the pavement for all to see, so I reckon the beef was pretty fresh.

After this we head back to the hostel where we met a great group of travellers and almost all of us in the hostel interacted. We enjoyed each others company for one night before we all head into the jungle or the pampas, a more swampy area, in our separate ways.

Me and H chose the Jungle, we had heard you see less animals but we really wanted to enter into the amazon and trek around. The boat ride in was amazing and filled us with excitement for the next 3 days. Upon arrival we also caught our first glimpse of wildlife, the shy Caiman just chilling next to the waters edge.

Going from Buenos Aires -> Santiago -> La Paz -> Rurrenabaque -> the Amazon really gave us a gradual integration into less developed areas and we were fully ready.

We began by smashing some sugar cane for the local community of which our guides were from and who live nearby in the jungle. They tend to live for half of the year in their community and half of the year in Rurrenabaque for tourism. They are also not deemed indigenous because they speak Spanish. Our guide Simon, pronounced Simone, also spoke English and had a very relaxed style. We pretty swiftly found ourselves calling him Simon but as he could only call us Mark and Harry Potter it seemed fair game.

Upon arrival at the lodge we had ourselves a lovely chicken lunch and a chill in the hammocks before heading out on first trek. Now I say chill. But of course the amount of bugs in the jungle is ridiculous. As we lay in the hammocks, the large ants paraded along them and the constant buzzing was only briefly interrupted by the beautiful and curious noises of the birds. I don't like things that buzz by my head. Particularly the wasps. The ants were actually pretty chill and there were some kinda cute little stingless bees who just eat the salt out of our sweat but still, mozzys and other unidentified flying things were not letting me chill to the extent I wanted to. But if I want to see and hear the birds, of which there were a lot, then I had to take the insects with em', buzzing and all.

There were other brands of ants, the less amiable 'army ants' who all just march together and eat whatever is in their sight, thankfully not us, and the bullet ant who is absolutely hench and as Simon says "make the human very sick". He tells the tale of a German lad who did not believe him and instead grabbed the ant, feeling the bite and the sting before dealing with 24 hours of pain. Simon smiles as he tells this story.

We embarked on our first trek along with the French couple in our group, all wide eyed and searching the floor and the canopy for signs of life. For the majority we only got insects and mostly ants but boy were they impressive. Leaf carrier ants who would bite off small chunks of leaves from the trees, bring from down the tree and carry them for miles to lay down in their colony where they would wait for them to decompose and flourish into mushrooms to eat. At times when it got too hot they lay down their leaves and head off in search of another task awaiting for the temoerature to cool before returning to finish the job. Incredibly smart, there were thousands of them all walking along road networks which stretched all along our trek. They dominated the jungle.

Harry and I had originally banned the game 'odds on' in the jungle as the potential for harm was too high stakes, however he did get me to shank our guide with a stick on a scale of 30/1. Simon didn't mind and as the days went by he became more and more playful with us. Many times mugging off other guides by making jaguar sounds or on two occasions trying to mug Harry Potter off with two wooden animals.

Back to the first trek, we also got the chance to see and hear some more exotic birds and just as we returning to the lodge we stumbled across a group of howler monkeys sitting atop the trees in their pack as they do, the dominant male keeping his watchful eye on us as we stared in awe. Harry also made sure he kept his eye on them. If you look closely you'll see the monkeys at the top of tree.

We returned happy and hungry to eat the communities special dish which is catfish cooked in a certain type of leaf found in the jungle and it was so tasty. Bolivia was fast putting itself at the height of South American cuisine for me.

On full stomachs we headed out for our night walk and I won't lie to you, I was feeling sketch, with cheap torches and a slight fear of bugs I was content with seeing nothing but of course this was not the case, seeing two tarantulas not 10 metres from where we would be sleeping. This is before we even head into the jungle. It had the same fearfulness and exhilaration of watching a scary movie you are very into. Except you are in it. With every stop or sound I found my first reaction always being a verbal 'No' and had turned to Harry on several occasions as Simon was poking nests and prodding around mean looking spiders. In the end the only thing to fear was the fear itself as we saw little after our first 10 minutes and I returned to nice common cockroaches in the lodge.

The second day we made our way to the campsite which I was beginning to regret, thinking of the bugs. On the way we saw two beautiful birds, one making a ridiculous sound called a 'screaming piha' and then spying two parakeets munching on Acai berries high above us. I was using my camera to get a good view and in that moment just watching them feed, you find yourself completely focused and watching their every move. I have some great pictures and videos but cannot yet get them off my camera, I'll have to show them to y'all in person. Myself and H spoke a lot about the feeling nature photographers must get when they snap their shot, using the end of Attenborough's documentaries as references. Seeing nature live truly is amazing.

It became even more amazing in the afternoon as we headed to the Macaw cliff where we witnessed up to 14 Macaws at a time squawking at each other as they took flight in couples around our heads. They are monogamous birds and will not mate with another if their partner dies, it seems that they do everything together and in perfect harmony. We even saw a fight between two birds with what could have been a fight for a mate as it was pretty much instigated by the one lonesome bird hanging around. They fought, they chased, they squawked in what is a horrible sound for such beautiful birds; bright red with green and blue feathers complementing. We could have stayed there for hours but instead returned for another nice meal and a night camping which was less sketchy than I would have thought. Unfortunately again all my pictures and videos are on the other camera but just trust me on these birds.

Unfortunately our time in the jungle was coming to an end, we were both saddened by this fact and could have spent more time there if it wern't for budget issues but we finished with a bang, trekking through the jungle, across an open desert like plain to the river where we were to build a raft. I say that but Simon pretty much built it whilst we held the logs in place or mucked about on the river bed. We began to paddle down the river, Francois swiftly de-oaring me and dashing my dreams of really being Moana. He took the lead until harry began to paddle at the front of the boat. We began to tilt the boat from side to side as Harry tried with all his might to stay afloat and keep balanced. Annoyingly he did not fall in.

It all finished with a swim in the river, a good temperature with thankfully no piranhas in it or none of those fish that swim up your dick. Although we did have a poisonous millipede on board which makes the human sick for a while. With Francois pulling his reluctant to swim girlfriend in, he began a series of events including a battle for the raft and Harry pulling Simon in. A great way to end what was a truly amazing couple of days. We will never forget them and as we head back it signalled the end of our trip as Harry and I go our seperate ways. We spent a few days making our way back to La Paz and feeling the exact opposite in terms of our gradual re-introduction into more developed areas.

Harry has gone to Brazil again where he will spend the remainder of his time with his girlfriend Hannah and I am currently writing this on a bus towards Cusco where I will stay for a month or so exploring the old Incan ruins including Macchu Picchu.

What a unforgettable weekend.
